Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I accept all challengers. No prior notice necessary.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You have returned. *<Snort> *I'm always ready to oppose you.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You enter my chamber once again, short one. Then, good.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I expected you to reappear. *<Snort> *Let us fight.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Appears it's time we challenged one another once again. Prepare.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Good. *<Snort> *It feels as though I haven't crushed the life from anything in ages.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Returned to battle me for glory, short one? *<Snort> *Excellent.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Come fight me again, short one. We have eternity to grow stronger.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Thank you, short one. *<Snort> *Few in Elysium dare challenge me repeatedly.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: The short one from the bowels of hell has finally returned.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I heard you had again entered Elysium. *<Snort> *At last.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Hold nothing back against me, short one. Now, come.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Let us grow stronger in the ways of battle, short one.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I always am prepared to fight whoever dares oppose me.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Let us battle now before you face the Champion, himself.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You seek the Champion. You must confront me, first.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Hrmm. *<Snort> *It has been long enough since my last fight.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I've been waiting for another round against you. Let's go. Now.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: They said you were headed this way. *<Snort> *I said I'd stop you. Though, we'll see.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Each time we fight... I think I learn a little more. Let's start.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I had a feeling you would cross my path again. I've been looking forward to this.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I'm going to run you down, or run you through. Your choice, short one.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Told the king I'd try to stop you on the way. He thought I'd have no trouble. *<Snort> *We'll see.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Come on, short one. I've been waiting too long for this.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You know what it takes to leave this chamber alive, short one. *<Snort> *Come on and fight.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I have my armor, short one. Let's see what you have.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Let's see if you can cut through my coat this time.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: This armor's heavy. But makes me even faster than before. *<Snort> *Watch.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You are resilient, short one, I will give you that.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I'm prepared to slaughter you again, short one. Come fight.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Interesting. *<Snort> *Most never challenge me again once I destroy them.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: What hope have you against the Champion, if you can't get through me?

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You have tenacity, short one. I have to give you that.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You do not take all your defeats to heart, do you? That's good.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You're quick, short one. Let's see if you can get past me again.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Well, short one. I'm curious to see if you can best me once again.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: A worthy challenger returns. Let's see you defeat me again.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Glory and honor to you if you can vanquish me again. Come!

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I welcome the taste of defeat, short one. It is akin to feeling alive.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I'm still learning all your tricks, short one. Come show me more.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Let's see you get through me again, short one.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I'm the one to challenge *you *this time, short one.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I have looked forward to repaying you in kind for our last fight.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You're strong, short one. But I am just as obstinate as you.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: The Champion awaits, short one. If you can get through me again, that is.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Good. Now I can get you back for last time. All I need is one clean hit.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Well fought. Though, your technique pales in comparison to that of the Champion of Elysium. I expect you'll soon see for yourself.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: I respect your strength, short one. The Champion of Elysium awaits. Until such time.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You were a worthy challenger. Most welcome here. Until we meet again.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: You have earned your passage. I go now to recover for the next occasion that we meet.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Thank you for sparring with me, short one. I'm glad we've made a habit of it thus.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: *Urgh*... the might of Gilgamesh... I understand it now. But I won't make his friend's mistake. We'll fight again.

Speaker: Minotaur
Text: Such strength... the strength of Gilgamesh. Thank you for the battle, short one.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You now know that, even if you are able to surpass me, you shall ultimately perish, soon enough. And yet you still persist! Utterly senseless.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I found her, Father. And I'm going to find Mother again. And again, and again, until I have some answers, finally. She'd like some answers, too, beginning with *why did you never tell her that I lived*? You let her go, and left her to her grief!

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Silence*, boy! Save all your ignorant and baseless accusations. You seem incapable of heeding my request that you not blather on about a matter you shall never understand. Then, I shall save my breath for this fight!

Speaker: Hades
Text: You were never supposed to live. Took all of Nyx's strength to circumvent what should have been a certainty. Now you cannot stay dead. Such is the wry humor of the Fates.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Nyx saved me.... So according to the Fates I was never meant to be born, since neither you nor Mother are of the Underworld, something like that? Or was that just another lie you told, to Mother and whoever else?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Bah! *You think everything a lie. The realm beneath our feet was appointed to me on certain conditions, not that I had much of a choice. Among them: A one-time surface-dweller such as I would never have an heir.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You really believed that? Then why attempt to have a child, anyway?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You don't know anything! Why anyone would *choose *to have a child is a mystery to me. The Fates said I would never have an heir. Perhaps *this *was all they meant.

Speaker: Hades
Text: To think Olympus has been aiding you. You must be so grateful to them for their aid, without which none of this would have been possible.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Yeah, about that. Father, did... did you let Mother go because you feared Olympus would find out? And... not respond well to the circumstances if they did?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Tsch. *Be grateful they have not found out as yet, for all your meddling. You do not know them as well as you think. Ask yourself why she left Olympus, and how. Or better yet, ask *her*.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well, she seems quite lovely, so... knowing you, you probably tricked her into signing a pact to come join you, or something. Since you weren't allowed on Olympus, why not have Olympus come to you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hah*! Surprisingly not distant from the truth. I took her, boy! I took her down with me. Is that what you wish to hear? Does that anger you? Come, bring forth that anger, then!

Speaker: Hades
Text: So, boy. Did you ask her? About how she came to join me in the Underworld. Did you confirm all your suspicions, then?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You didn't drag her down to hell, yourself, apparently. You're not going to tell me who did, though I can well imagine. Your brothers got to reign forever on Olympus, while you got sent down into the Underworld. So they gave you a consolation prize... didn't they?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You make such accusations, knowing next to nothing. Careless as ever. Poseidon had nothing to do with it! He knows even less than you. If you value her existence or your own, you would be wise to keep it that way. And to turn back!

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...She was the Queen. Queen of the Underworld! My Queen. Commanding reverence, and awe, and fear. She was not just... what was the term you used? A *consolation prize*? You are as disrespectful to her as you are to me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, what would you even know?! You claim so much respect for her, yet you didn't even respect her enough to tell her what happened after she left! But... what am I saying... I know you love her, still, Father. That best explains all the terrible choices you've made.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...All the terrible choices I've made. By the time you have existed for as long as I have, pray you will have made fewer. Although I fear you shall surpass me in at least this one regard.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I have done virtually everything within my power to prevent this. All of it... for nothing. The Fates were not content to saddle me within the earth; they mock me, still.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Maybe they just think you're in the wrong. And that you're an obstinate, overbearing, miserable excuse for a husband and father. Don't you understand I'm trying to fix the problems you caused? Since you're so unwilling to do it yourself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You're right. I was unwilling. I made my choices, in all this. I loved her, yes. I loved her terribly. But now... it seems I am merely delaying the inevitable. Go, then. Go to her. But, should harm befall her... I shall bring my worst wrath upon whomever is to blame... including you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What? You're letting me go, just like that? You're just afraid of getting struck down again. You're serious?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Heh. *Confronting you like this... it's different now. Still... it is a responsibility, just as before. There is to be no escape from my realm. Ultimately, I must see to that, myself.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: That's the spirit, Father! As for me, I find the candor of our interactions here to be rather refreshing, I must say. Especially the interactions between my weapons and your physique. You're tough, but you're an easy target.

Speaker: Hades
Text: And you are scrawny, though slippery, blast you. All that pent-up rage behind your smiling words... come, unleash it once again. I expect you to go all out. To the death!

Speaker: Hades
Text: I was reviewing the terms of the Pact of Punishment to which you are bound. Even when my servants resort to extreme measures, they were still unable to surpass you, then. So now, it is my turn.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Caught you unprepared, did I? After Theseus and his Macedonian, I half-expected to see you thundering around on some golden chariot of your own, drawn by sable steeds, that sort of thing. But it's just you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It is just me, indeed. However... that should be more than necessary, here. No holding back this time, Zagreus. Are you ready?

Description: Lord Hades Has Guan Yu Aspect 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: What have you done with my ancient weapon, boy? I sense Varatha's form there in your feeble grip, but... there's some garish power you've awakened in it, haven't you?

Description: Lord Hades Has Guan Yu Aspect 01
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, just took a splash of Titan Blood at the right time was all. There's more to your ancient weapon than you gave it credit for, I guess. Though let's not keep it waiting, no?

Description: Lord Hades Has Guan Yu Aspect 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: No, let's not. Gigaros is the mightier weapon, with none of the treacherous past. It needs no fanciful shape-shifting tricks to run you through. Behold!

Speaker: Hades
Text: I never had any respect for Stygius, that blade you bear. Perhaps unfairly, due to Brother Poseidon's sloppy form when once he wielded it. But now it seems quite different in your care.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I think we've grown quite close to one another, yes. Enough to where I've come to know a different side of this fine blade right here. This is the aspect of some Arthur fellow! Maybe the two of you could get acquainted properly?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Arthur! *No name either of gods or kings of any realm I know. Then, introduce us, as you say! To this new amateur, to whom your blade rendered its services.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The bow is the weapon of a coward, boy. I said so even to Hera's face. I'm unsurprised that you are drawn to it, and yet... something has changed about it, I can tell.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What, you mean that Coronacht has taken on the aspect of a divine preserver person of some sort, of whom I've seen mere glimpses but seems definitely very capable, and really rather brave?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I know not why the old Infernal Arms endear themselves to you. And, I entirely care not in whose weakling aspect you bring them forth, only to fall to me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: There you are, bearing my brother's blasted shield... flaunting it about so recklessly. Though, what have you done to it, now?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Not much, really, besides awakening the aspect of a supposedly unstoppable, dragon-slaying warrior called Beowulf. If it has the power to protect him against a giant lizard, I figure it may help me against you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You presently shall find I'm no mere giant lizard, boy. Though we shall see whether this Beowulf is any help to you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Resorting to mere fisticuffs with me... though, how you got Malphon to look like that, I've no idea. Pray tell, whose monstrous claws are those? A manticore's?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: These claws, I'll have you know, Father, belonged once to an ancient god-king known as Gilgamesh. You ever meet?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hrm*. Provided he was flesh and blood at some point, then he resides within my realm. Presumably within Elysium somewhere, sadly bereft of his manticore claws, thanks to you. Come, show me what they can do.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You approach me with that loathsome Rail, boy. Emanating a hellish fury more even than usual, at that. Little surprise you took a shine to it. It was the weapon that I hated most of all.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well, someone called Lucifer apparently thought differently, and took a crack at his own father with it, once. This one's for him, then.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Invoking names you know nothing about. Presuming, all the while, far too much. You take that monstrous artifact for another friend? You would be wiser to be wary of its influence. But, let us fight.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ah*, but there you are, boy, finally. Despite my knowing you are always late for everything, here you've outdone yourself by quite some time.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh shut up, and get your fork, and burn away that regal cape, and let's get to this, then. I'd no idea you had all these capes to spare! Must have a whole entire storage chamber full of them.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your mockery of me may temporarily embolden you, but achieves nothing useful, in the end.

Speaker: Hades
Text: This cold white substance falling slowly from the heavens. Snow, they call it. Look carefully upon each fleck. Tiny crystals! But structurally weak. They melt! This surface realm... it is held up by mine.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: If you're quite finished teaching me about this snow phenomenon, can we get on with brutally trying to kill each other, here?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You wish to have your mortal-colored blood spill once again upon this bed of snow, then fine. Let us proceed.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You still have yet to see the sun itself. You know only the light of Ixion, but the sun? It is positively blinding. Hideous.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It has been snowy nightfall every single time now that you mention it. I didn't know it snowed so much up here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It hasn't always. But, that's of no consequence to us. Especially when there's a raging battle to be fought.

Speaker: Hades
Text: If you are here, then... the Olympians must still be lending you their aid. Just as before! I scarce believe the Queen's preposterous idea worked. That all it took to settle an old score was a blasted family feast.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Come on, Father, even you must have enjoyed that feast to some extent. We ought to do it more often! Good thing you trusted Mother's judgment on that one. So, then, to the death, once more?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Indeed. To the death, as always, boy. Zagreus. Ready yourself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I never grew accustomed to the air, up here. It gusts senselessly whichever way it pleases. I suppose you must prefer it to the stillness of the air below.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know, you're right. The air up here seems pretty good so far. But I will reserve judgment till I've had my fill. I have to say, though, Father: The Helm of Darkness suits you. I'm touched you'd dust it off on my account.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It should not have had to come to this. For all your antics with me and around the House, I always kept my temper, have I not? Unlike you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well, let's see. You've berated me repeatedly and often. You've lied to me. Mustered your wretched forces to kill me, over and over. But, sure, I'll grant you that you've always kept most of your anger bottled up. All that's about to change, then?

Speaker: Hades
Text: We're gods, boy. Killing one another is our lot. Although, I always thought I was above it. I told you that you cannot leave this place. It seems I must enforce my rules myself. I'm sending you home, now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I never grew accustomed to the air, up here. It gusts senselessly whichever way it pleases. I suppose you must prefer it to the stillness of the air below.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know, you're right. The air up here seems pretty good so far. But I will reserve judgment till I've had my fill. I have to say, though, Father: The Helm of Darkness suits you. I'm touched you'd dust it off on my account.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It should not have had to come to this. For all your antics with me and around the House, I always kept my temper, have I not? Unlike you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well let's see. You've berated me repeatedly and often. You've lied to me. Mustered a bunch of incompetent wretches to try to kill me. But, sure, I'll grant you that you've always kept most of your anger bottled up. All that's about to change, then?

Speaker: Hades
Text: We're gods, boy. Killing one another is our lot. Although, I always thought I was above it. I told you that you cannot leave this place. It seems I must enforce my rules myself. I'm sending you home, now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You know now what you're doing here is without any purpose whatsoever. Even if I don't slay you myself, you'll simply perish when you cross that threshold there. And yet you still persist?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I do. Besides, making these treks helps pass the time during the ongoing Underworld renovations. And I'll be in tiptop shape once they're complete!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Would that we had a little more support; the renovations could have been complete by now! As ever, you think only of yourself. But if you must insist like this, then you will find me waiting for you once you get here. Every single time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Why? Why do you keep showing up? In spite of knowing that the outcome shall be just the same as how it always was?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Beats having to toil away under your overbearing supervision. And besides, as you may be aware, I've recently made up my mind to leave this place.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Eughh*... utterly incorrigible. When next we meet here, then, we'll keep it brief. I have grown weary of our aimless conversations. Now prepare!

Speaker: Hades
Text: You bear the Sigil of the Dead. I wear the Helm of Darkness. Even devoid of artifacts as these, we fight here without witnesses... in shadow.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: If only everybody knew you had a mighty son most capable of cutting you down to size, with or without the ability to vanish suddenly.

Speaker: Hades
Text: A very boastful son, who often thinks too much of his ability. Come, then! I'll make you vanish suddenly.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...That pomegranate blossom... I caught its subtle scent as you approached. The Queen has her mother's strength. And much more self control.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What, you're afraid of a little flower, now, Father? One that imbues me with the fiercest might of Olympus, granted, but still! It looks harmless, at least.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I fear your little flower there much more than you. The Queen and her mother... they possess power over life. Thus, power over death.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Extreme measures permitted, even still? You must have forgotten to change the conditions of your Pact of Punishment.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Wasn't an oversight. You're strong, Father. I want to be as strong, and more. Not that I'm taking after you, or anything.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You wish to test yourself against the full extent of my wrath, then very well. You have earned that right. Besides yourself, only the Titans have. Now, then... *attack*!

Speaker: Hades
Text: You vanquished me... even when I threw everything I had at you, and more. I fought you as I fought the Titans themselves, and still I failed.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, don't take it so hard, Father. There's always next time, right? Meaning, this time. Maybe I won't be so fortunate.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Of that, I am most certain. Come, let us see the limits of our abilities, then. I warn you: I shall hold nothing back. To the death!

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Nary a whif of Mount Olympus on you, this time. How is it that you clambered all this way, without the generous support of your dear family? Doubtless you merely purged their blessings for some coin.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey, I resent that, Father! I'm more than capable of getting here all on my own, now, thanks.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Such arrogance has led to many a mortal's downfall... and many a god's.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Odd. No stink of Olympus on you, this time. Have you truly come all this way without assistance from your relatives? Or were you overzealous at a Pool of Purging?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Wouldn't you like to know? Not even Nyx believed that I could come this far without aid from the Olympians. Maybe I just have a knack for proving everybody wrong.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You have a *knack *for being struck down in various, ignoble ways, that much is certain. Come, then! Show me what you, yourself, can do!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Be still. These waters... teeming with Poseidon's river denizens. That one there, before me... it's been taunting me, I think, for quite some time.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You offering to take me *fishing*, Father? Sounds more pleasant than having you slaughter me again, or the other way around.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You mistook my meaning. First, *you *shall have my spear. Then, that thing shall, if it has not yet come to its senses. Though, if you vanquish me, I'm certain your uncle shall not mind if you extract it, yourself.

Description: Lord Hades Pact High Heat Reaction 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: It is a testament to the awful might of Demeter that, even with the surge of heat created by the Pact of Punishment you toy with recklessly, this place remains a frozen waste.

Description: Lord Hades Pact High Heat Reaction 01
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: The Pact did make the road here a little more fraught than usual. But if it couldn't stop me, I can't imagine it could stop Demeter.

Description: Lord Hades Pact High Heat Reaction 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: Forget her, and the blasted Pact. I'll stop you, myself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Enjoying the delicate warmth of the surface, b-- Zagreus? Apparently, the generosity of the goddess of seasons knows no bounds.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Does feel a bit different, maybe. Though, Demeter said something about how this spot, in particular, would remain bereft of warmth, as a reminder. Do you think she knows what happened with Mother, really?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Demeter may harbor vengeful feelings and suspicions, but she is no fool. Experience teaches us to know when to quit. Though, evidently, that is a lesson you have yet to learn.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Look at yourself, boy. You barely stand, and yet believe you can surpass me in your current state?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It's not exactly easy getting here, you know. But I'm not going back. Not yet.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Perhaps not yet. But very, very soon.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Varatha... I recognize its presence, now. That's not just any three-pronged lance you wield. I could never stand to look at it, once my brothers and my sisters and myself... once our foul work was done.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You mean once you'd chopped up your cruel and overbearing Titan parents, right? Shame you threw it out. It's quite useful.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Perhaps the Fates decided that its wielders ought to all eventually wind up on its receiving end. Come, then! Let us see what the great Achilles has taught you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: So! You think that you can vanquish me with my fool brother's old, forgotten blade. Poseidon was never any good with Stygius. Grew envious of my spearwork. Now he's famous for that fork of his! Always taking credit where none is due.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Must be hard, knowing that everybody's going to think you learned your spearwork from Poseidon, not the other way around. As for Stygius, I can assure you it's in good hands now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your assurances mean nothing to me, boy. You think yourself quite capable? Then show me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You come here bearing brother Zeus' Aegis. I wonder how much more insulting you could be.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What? I haven't even started to insult you here yet, Father. Flustered by the old Shield of Chaos, then?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Doubtless Zeus does not even remember wielding it. I never should have relied on him for anything after that! Then, come. Let's see if you're any better with it than your great uncle.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hrm*. It grew distinctly colder just as you arrived. So *Demeter *has been in contact with you, then. That witch. Tell me how much she knows.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What? I don't... wait, this everlasting winter, it's her doing, isn't it? Why? Don't mortals die when it's cold? Sounds like a lot of extra work for you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Then you are ignorant. Keep it that way, with her. Lest you risk everything, you understand? The consequences would be far worse than a foul stretch of weather. But, enough talk, now.

Description: Lord Hades About Eternal Winter 01 B
Speaker: Hades
Text: Hrm. It grew distinctly colder just as you arrived. So Demeter has been in contact with you, then. That witch. Tell me how much she knows.

Description: Lord Hades About Eternal Winter 01 B
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: She lost her daughter... who's my mother. But, Demeter still thinks I'm Nyx's son, and... what have you done, Father? This everlasting winter, it's her doing, isn't it? Freezing mortals to death. Why don't you stop this?

Description: Lord Hades About Eternal Winter 01 B
Speaker: Hades
Text: The two of you know nothing, then, it seems. Keep it that way, especially with her. Lest you risk everything, you understand? The consequences would be far worse than a foul stretch of weather. But, enough talk, now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...The sea... the heavens, and the earth. All of this belongs to my brothers. We are their kin by birth. But we are foreigners in their country.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: No. No mournful speeches. Now get out of my way.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You impertinent brat. Fine. Impulsiveness runs in the family.

Speaker: Hades
Text: There was a time when Cerberus would never have permitted any soul to exit through that gateway there behind you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, that can't possibly be true! What about Orpheus, Theseus, Heracles, Odysseus? Countless tales of brave men delving into the Underworld, then leaving whence they came!

Speaker: Hades
Text: They left on my authority alone. Nor did they take for granted my good graces. You believe you are entitled simply to walk out of here. From your birthright and your responsibilities! But I am here to tell you, *no*.

Speaker: Hades
Text: My brothers and my sisters and myself. We, too, wanted to slay our parents. The Titans. Bastards. And worse.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: And you succeeded. Chopped up some of them into many tiny bits, and sprinkled them throughout the pits of Tartarus so that they can't regenerate! Or so I hear. Inspiring, really!

Speaker: Hades
Text: We had no recourse at the time, save to collaborate. Developed a specific plan, and saw it through. And, the Titans...? You think me cruel, yet know nothing of cruelty. But, here, you want something to hate, then have it!

Speaker: Hades
Text: I must admit to something, boy. Achilles taught you reasonably well. I expected that if anyone could train you into martial competence, it would be him.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Though you didn't expect that, one day, I would end up using everything I learned from him against *you*.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I anticipate more than you know. But Achilles merely practiced against mortals. Now, you practice against *me*.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Come all this way again, to fall to me? Would that you paid me such respects back at the House.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What is it going to take for you to understand that your place is in the House?!

Speaker: Hades
Text: I shall give you no quarter, boy. Although I doubt that you expected otherwise.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The sea and air are very still this eve. Though I suppose that is about to change.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Know only that I take no pleasure in what I am now forced to do.

Speaker: Hades
Text: There you are. Then let us now commence this ugly business yet again.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The heavens and the seas belong to my brothers; but know that you are still in *my *domain.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You bypassed Cerberus again, I see. Unfortunately for the both of us.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I had other pressing business to attend to. But I cannot let you leave.

Speaker: Hades
Text: No matter how many times you try, your stubbornness shall get you nowhere with me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You're back, with Stygius in hand. Come then, and show me your technique!

Speaker: Hades
Text: The Blade of the Underworld cannot help you here, you realize that, boy?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your heart-seeking Coronacht may have brought you this far, but shall not help you, here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: That heart-seeking bow you wield... it is nothing but a tool for cowards, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: So, Varatha and Gigaros are to clash again upon this empty field. Let us have at it, then.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I knew someday the Eternal Spear would turn on me. Let's see you wield it, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The Shield of Chaos... what a monstrous thing. How suitable for you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You bear the Aegis so much like your uncle Zeus once did.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You think the Rail of Adamant can vanquish me? We'll momentarily find out.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You would take aim at me with Exagryph? Then, very well.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You would attack me with the savagery of the Twin Fists? Then, come.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Again, you seek to use the power of Malphon against me. Fine.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You are predictable in your arrivals here. Less so during the fight itself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I was just thinking on when last I vanquished you. Come, refresh my memory.

Speaker: Hades
Text: No matter how often you defeat me, I shall face you here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Remember, I can always get here much, much faster than you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: No matter how quickly you're able to get here, I shall be waiting.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Again, you draw me from all my responsibilities back at the House.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I cannot let you go, boy. Some night such as this one, you'll understand.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I shall be interested to see if you can vanquish me again, here, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Come, show me everything you've learned of how to fight.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You've slipped by Cerberus again, I see. Then, draw your weapon, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I see it's time again that we begin our bloody business here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: This blasted place... how can you even stand it on the surface, here?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Who shall be first to return home this time, do you suppose?

Speaker: Hades
Text: It seems it's time again I sent you home, myself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your rampage through my realm ends here and now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I thought you might arrive right about now. Then, let us have our fight.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You'll go not one step farther past this threshold, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The world beyond my realm is not for you. You're going home.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I wonder, boy, who's going to kill whom this time around.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I cannot fathom why you wish to die repeatedly like this.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Already here? It seems our Underworld still has many failings I shall have to deal with, after this.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Come show your father what you've learned of late. Do not hold back.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Would that you cleaned your chambers with the same devotion you show getting to these heights.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Untold murderous wretches in my realm, all at my beck and call, yet still you made it here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You have circumvented all of my security measures again. But can you get through *me*?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I trust you have retained enough of your strength through this ordeal to make this worth our while?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Catch your breath if necessary, and then let us see if you shall earn your bonus for this day.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Bah*! Not one of my overseers managed to stop you, again? Must I do everything myself?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I've other work to get to! Arm yourself, and let us end this quickly, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It seems our realm has many weaknesses. I shall deal with them shortly, then.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Let us see if the support you're getting from Olympus amounts to anything of use.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Blast, but you're persistent, even now! Though let us see how strong you are, as well.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I should be getting back to my desk. But I suppose the work can wait.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ah*, there you are, boy! I was beginning to think I'd need a thicker cloak.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Well, Zagreus. Even if I vanquish you, arriving here is a sufficient feat.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I must admit, this is a welcome change of pace from all the parchmentwork.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I suppose that you must be eager to repay me for last time, then?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I expect I shall be able to vanquish you again. Though, we shall see.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Perhaps the blasted Fates shall favor *me*, for once.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Our last exchange left much to be desired, for my part. But this time, we shall see.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...*Tsch*. To have been brought this low... by my own ungrateful child. I would expect such treatment from my brothers, but from you...? *Nrrrgghhh*....

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Such contempt, for your own father. But we are not finished here, yet.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Your youth provides you with a certain mindless strength. But, such power has its limits.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Now that we had our little warm-up, it is time that we began in earnest.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...You strike at your own father. What choice does that leave me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...*Hmph*. All right, then, boy. You've stirred my anger suitably, by now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*... no... I'm... not... finished... with you... *yet*!!

Speaker: Hades
Text: I... how... you.... Go. Go, then. *Go*!! Get out of here! Get out!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I told you that I would, Father. And I'm going to. Goodbye.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Wait. Wait, just... if you... if you find her. If you somehow find her? Tell her something for me, tell her... Tell her Cerberus is doing very well.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What? Wait. I don't think I owe you any favors, here. Though, answer me one question, and I'll give it some thought, how's that?

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I know your question, boy. But, ask it anyway.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Persephone. My mother. Why did she leave?

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I... urgh... blood and darkness...

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're not going to cooperate with me on this, are you? Even now, knowing Mother wants to see me again?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*! Blast you... you shall ruin everything... with all your damnable questions!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Then, die, already. And get the hell out of my way.

Description: Lord Hades Chaos Surface Quest Defeat 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Blast you, boy... we should have never sprung from Chaos... none of this...

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*.... *<Gasp> *How... I... I went all out! And still...?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Blast you, boy. You think you are superior to me? You are a fool.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh...! *With your youth comes a certain strength, it seems.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Tsch... *I... I shall see you back at home.

Speaker: Hades
Text: How? How is this possible, that this... *urgh!*

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ungh... *The world you seek out there... it's even crueler than the one you know.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Augh! *Why... I was much stronger once, than this...

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Aah, blast*! That you of all my kin would be the one, to do this, to me....

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Mmph*... No matter how many times you beat me... we're family. There's no escaping that.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Again, you have defeated me, somehow. And yet...

Speaker: Hades
Text: What shall it take... what shall it take for you to...

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ungh, *you... tell no one at the House. Do you hear me?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Rrngh*, you stubborn... you shrug off death as though it means nothing to you...!

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I shall keep coming back... the same as you...!

Speaker: Hades
Text: You... you think that you're the only one... who shall keep fighting?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I must admit... you've learned something. At some point, in all this.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*... were it not for all my wretched kin upon Olympus, you...

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Rngh*, vanquished again... by my own fool kin....

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Guh*! Boy, you speak none of this, to anyone!

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*! How did... you accomplish this...?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Nrgh*! You cannot escape... none of us can.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Augh*... then, go, see what awaits you in this realm...

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Gah*... I, fell to you, again, I... how...?

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Gah*... you have your mother's perseverance. How is it that you got this strong?

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 02
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urngh*! It seems... I was no match for you, this time.

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 03
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Augh*... I'm not as limber as I used to be, while you...?

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 04
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Nngh*... for a student of Achilles... I fear that you surpass even his skill, by now...

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 05
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Umphh*... you broke through every one of my defenses, once again...

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 06
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Argh*... you bested me, I'll grant you, Zagreus...

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 07
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ungh*... Olympus gave you quite the edge against me, then...

Description: Lord Hades Misc Post Ending Defeat 08
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Grngh*... you owe this victory to all your relatives...

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Mmmrrrrnnn*....

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know, Charon, your associate Hermes apparently had a wager with you that I could beat you twice in a row at some point? I'd hate to disappoint him, so... no hard feelings?

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Nnnrrrraaaaaauugggghhh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Haaahhhhh*....

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *Erm*, Charon, look, I can explain. It's just, I've grown very accustomed to taking stuff throughout my father's realm. I wasn't stealing from you, honestly!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Mmnnn*rraaauuugggghhh*!!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: That was not an understanding sound. Wait, why are you brandishing your oar in such a menacing way?

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Haaahhhhh*....

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're just testing me, here, right, Charon? I mean, when you place a huge sum of coin conspicuously within my reach, what do you expect me to do?

Speaker: Charon
Text: Nrrnnhhh, hnnnn, hrrnn, *hrrrrrnnn*...

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Sounds good, mate, when I rob you from now on it's just my way of saying *Charon, I would like to battle you to the death right now for a quick change of pace*.

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Hrrrnnnggghh*....

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Grrnrnhh, rrraahhh*!

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Hrraaaahhhhhh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Hrrn... *grrraaauuuggghh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Rrnn... *hhrraaaauuuggghh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Grrr... *nrrraauuuggghhh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Urrh... *urraaauuuggghh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Krrr... *krraauuuggghh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Hhh, *hrreehhhhh*!!

Speaker: Charon
Text: Haahh, nrraugh, *haaaaah*!!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Got you, mate! Twice in a row. I guess Hermes wins his little wager with you, then. You tell him I said *hrrrrrnnnggghh*!

Speaker: Charon
Text: *Hrrrrrnnnggghh*...

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Why, look, Zagreus, here comes brave Athena, first to reach you among all my kin, in all her shrewdness. So proactive, you contacted Zagreus prior to even telling me, my dear!

Speaker: Athena
Text: Lord Father, would that I could settle even more such matters quickly and discreetly, so that only the most vital of them rise up to the level of your notice, sir. Though, I'm certain Zagreus and I are very grateful you have intervened.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Nephew! By my divine authority, my oft-misunderstood son, Ares, now shall lend you a small token of his power. I'll make him helpful yet!

Speaker: Ares
Text: It shall be exactly as you say, Lord Father. Your wishes are identical to mine.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Young man, I know you'd like to get to know the comely Aphrodite face to face, or I don't know, you can decide once you arrive at last! He can decide, isn't that right, my Lady Aphrodite, hm?

Speaker: Aphrodite
Text: Why, I never, Lord Zeus! That sounded rather like a crass remark, from *you*! How shocking that the golden standard for the rest of us should have such words for *me*!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, Zagreus, once you arrive, we'll have to find for you a suitable mate, won't we? Fine young man such as yourself! Normally, there's much to choose from around here, with some exceptions, of course... such as my cunning daughter, Artemis. Willfully uninclined to take a mate, at all!

Speaker: Artemis
Text: Yes, Zagreus, in spite of all these perfect, chiseled prospects everywhere about, yearning to marry or embarrass me, for some reason, I prefer to spend my time mostly alone or with my nymph friends in the woods!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, now, young man, whatever you have heard about good Demeter, I'm here to clear the air. She's like a sister to me, yes, but only thus. Although her Titan parents and my own met the same fate.

Speaker: Demeter
Text: Why, Foster-Brother Zeus! Such an unlikely bit of candor there, from you! Almost as though you felt compelled to speak the truth only whilst I'm directly within earshot.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Have you encountered Exagryph and said to it the waking-phrase I gave to you, young man? Why, I'd tell Exagryph myself! Remember, it's *I see your prideful fall down from the heavens to the flames*.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now that is an entirely unusual design, even for Exagryph! So then the waking-phrase has worked. That aspect's bearer, Lucifer, was it? Struck his own lord father! Tried to, anyway. A not uncommon story it would seem.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I gather Lady Demeter's already got her frigid hold on you, certainly not the warmest member of the clan, now, is she? But do be patient with her, she's been through a lot.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My good sister Demeter already tried to poison you against me, as I understand, young man? Oh, *foster*-sister she prefers I say, loath as she is to accept her role as part of our great family.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You must forgive the Lady Demeter her scornfulness, Nephew, for she is still recovering after the sudden disappearance of her daughter, though it was quite some time ago the girl, *poof*! Just vanished. I try to lighten up the mood around it every now and then, but *no*, a sore spot, still!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Poor Demeter, young man. We still wonder what became of her fair daughter. Ran away with mortals, there, perhaps? Some of the tales, even more preposterous. Don't go believing everything you hear, and do be sensitive about the subject, hm? Demeter, she's been through quite enough.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: The Lady Demeter still prattles on about her missing girl, Zagreus. But I want you to understand something, all right? She's gone. We all have grieved. Perhaps Demeter shall finally accept what has occurred, and we can move forward, having grown stronger as a family.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Sure hope this works.... In the name of Hades! Olympus, this is an official message! For you, in all your splendor, Lord Uncle Zeus.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My, what is this you have for me, young man? Appears to be a message of some sort, bearing my thunder sigil! Though, there's one for everybody on Olympus? Have they as yet received their own? I must know what it says... it's from your father, who else could it be? I'd better check on this!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I eagerly await learning some more about the contents of that fascinating message you had sent up here, Nephew! How mysterious, indeed. I'll be keeping an eye on all the others that come in!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I have to tell you, Zagreus, that it was wonderful to meet with you, at last! We were so pleased to learn Persephone was safe! And Nyx, why, she's as stunning as they say. Shouldn't have lied to us about your parentage, but, I know things get complicated, here, and that what's done is done!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Poseidon sought you out already, hm? My boastful brother gets on with Lord Hades even worse than I, so let me put a little spark into his storms for you!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My brave daughter Athena beat me to you this time, has she? No matter, with her blessing and my own, you shall be nigh unstoppable!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Has lovely Aphrodite put you in a trance already, Zagreus? Or might I offer you the blessing of Olympus to intensify her catastrophic power with my own?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: So my elusive Artemis has shown you favor, has she? The little scamp, she seldom shows respect to anyone, not even me! But I'll enhance her blessing nonetheless.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Getting along with Ares, are you, Nephew? *Heh*. Would that you were my son instead of he, but no, I jest, I jest! Here, take my blessing, please!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: It pleases me to know, young man, that you and Dionysus have been getting on so well. He could use a level-headed friend, and you could use my blessing!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Hmm*! You've traveled rather quickly to this point... which reminds me, I've not seen swift Hermes anywhere of late! The rascal's likely dallying about!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Nephew, I have somewhat of a favor I must ask. You tell your father, if you so happen to run into him again, that his brother Zeus forgives him, and would like to reconnect, and welcome him into the family again. You tell him for me, hm?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: So you are son to Hades by that Nyx, the night-goddess, is that correct, Nephew...? Well I suppose she's closest to a queen as your lord father's like to find down there. I tried to match him up with some more wholesome types, but no, and here we are.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: After we learned about your plight and your existence from the goddess Nyx, all of us on Olympus rallied to assist you just as best we could. A family such as mine protects its own!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My brothers Hades and Poseidon once fought bravely by my side, you know that, don't you, Nephew? We prevailed against the Titans and established law upon the earth. Your father then descended to the land of death, and we've not seen much of each other since.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Your father must have told you that his governance over the Underworld is due more to the weaving of the Fates than by his choice. Admittedly, he got the short end of the stick. Whereas Poseidon and myself, why, we've been doing rather well indeed.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My brother Hades always was a lonesome man, you know. I pitied him! But I could never quite extract him from his thorny shell. Now he stews resentfully down there. You needn't bear the brunt of his frustrations.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Old Hades has continued to ignore my every effort to reach out to him, young man. Ah well, but he is obstinate, indeed. You are wise to seek your family's better half.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: By the way, Nephew, I hear-tell your mother Nyx is quite the catch! If you'll forgive my saying so, of course. Your father's never had much of a sensibility around companionship, though perhaps this concubine of his brought something out in him, at last!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: If and when you reach the surface, Zagreus, you call upon me then and there, all right? I'll personally see to it that you'll be escorted up to Olympus, and your quest shall be complete!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I know just how much you must want out of there, young man. And I want that as well! *Heh*. Good thing for you, as I get what I want around here. Ask anybody!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You fight your father's legions with Varatha, the Eternal Spear? The irony must not escape him, for he long ago stood by my side against the Titans, with that thing in hand!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: It seems the bow called Coronacht is safe and sound there in your hands, young man. I've not seen that old thing in quite some time!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: That shield of yours, called Aegis, why, in fact, it's mine from long ago, young man! I've no more need of it, of course, though how you found it, you shall have to tell me once you're here!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Well, if it isn't the one and only Rail of Adamant in your possession, there! To strike one's enemies from afar is really the only way, I think, and it's about as good a substitute for lightning bolts as you're likely to find!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, isn't that Malphon the Twin Fists there in your possession, Zagreus? Last god I saw bedecked in those old gloves was Demeter herself, oh, way back when! She was a real fighter at the time, not just a naysayer!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Ah*, now that's the Aegis that I know and love! Or *used *to love, at least, the dear old thing! Now I quite love these shocking bolts of mine. Though I am proud you've given Aegis a good home, and bear it in my name!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Hark, young man, for I've a vision I must share with you! A waking-phrase for Exagryph, to be precise. Please beseech the weapon thus: *I see your prideful fall down from the heavens to the flames. *An odd connection to a past or future bearer, apparently one who defied a god!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Nephew, I wanted to mention, it was odd how by every account you'd come quite close to breaking free from there at last, of late... only to be abruptly cut off from our contact! I suppose having suffered some ill fate? Perhaps your realm's guardian, Cerberus, is even deadlier than reputed!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Your dear mother Persephone is a shrewd woman, Zagreus. More than an equal to your mighty father! I'm pleased to know you've made amends with her, and taken new responsibilities within your House! Naturally, I'll continue to pitch in. And, I hope that we'll meet again, someday!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I must say, Nephew! Although it pleases me that we, here, reconnected with your father's realm... just between us, it pleases me even more that you are able to keep sticking it to him! You keep that up, all right?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Zagreus, you have a clever mother in Persephone! A very clever mother. And a lordly father! They make quite the team, that's evident! True rivals for Hera and me!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: The lord and ruler of Olympus and the world, why, he needs a healthy sense of humor, no, young man? Now there's an awful lot of spoil-sports out here, can't take even a little joke, well, I know all their mothers, fie on all of them, I say! Let's joke away!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I suppose even down in the Underworld, you would have heard such tales of me, young man. They're all untrue, *hahaha*! Except the tales of my bravery. Those are completely accurate, though all too modest, in most cases, I must say.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Ah, must be my gleaming Thunder Signet that I transferred to you! Why, I could feel its call from all the way up here!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Why you look positively dreadful, Zagreus. That place is doing you no favors, I can tell! Luckily, I'll do you favors aplenty!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You seem in dire need of some assistance, Nephew. So, of course, I dropped what I was doing and then sought you out as quickly as I could!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Zagreus, you must have left most of your lifeblood back the other way, *hahahaha*! Oh, I jest, I jest! But you look *terrible*.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: No, no one likes to die, young man! But since you seem about to any moment now, you keep your head held high, do you hear me?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Well, let's face it, Zagreus, you are as good as dead right now. But you'll just slosh right back out of the River Styx, and give it a good try again, won't you?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Remember, young man, dying is for mortals. So don't go making a habit of it, there! But if you have to do it, do it fighting, like a *hero *would!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I wonder, Nephew, whether you're prepared as yet to harness the surpassing power I shall grant you now? Don't take this blessing lightly, and may you use it well.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: How about, young man, we cease with all the trifling down there and cause a real storm for once? Take now the fiercest of my powers, and you show your no-good father what you're made of!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Is this really him? OK. In the name of Hades! Olympus! I accept this message.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Greetings there, young man! Look, your father's always been rather difficult, and he's not so much as called in quite some time. You'll have a better home where you belong, here on Olympus! And to help you on your journey, have my blessing.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: We meet again, young man! Yours isn't my affair, I know, and yet I cannot help but take an interest in your plight. Your father cast his lot; he need not take his anger out on you.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Hello, young man, and might I offer you a little taste of the heavens themselves? Though, don't go telling your old sulky father I've been spoiling you rotten!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I and all of us upon Olympus are anticipating your success, dear Nephew! Now let me see if I can't help spur you along.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Well, my nephew, you're admittedly in quite a bind down there, but what is life without its struggles, hm? You'll make it here, eventually, I'm certain.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I like the fire in you, Zagreus, and I have every confidence you'll someday clamber from the shadows there into the light!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Here on Olympus, Nephew, we take care of one another and support each other, quite unlike how it must be there in your father's grim domain. No wonder you intend to leave!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I'd ask you offer my respects to your lord father, Zagreus, but I suspect you won't have such a chance anytime soon, considering how far you'll come with my support!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Remember you've as many chances as it takes, young man, to fight your way out of the dark and join us in the splendor of Olympus!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Your grim-faced father's such a spoilsport, Nephew, the way he keeps impeding your escape. Ah, well, just keep at it, hm?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My greetings, young Nephew, and more importantly, my blessing and my strength be with you as you journey towards your rightful home.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Faith and courage, Zagreus, for each and every one of us upon Olympus is behind you all the way throughout this whole affair.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: What can I say, young man? You may not make your father very proud, but it is just the opposite with me! Now go, get out of there!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, Nephew, how about we put both of our backs into this one, and see to it that you go farther through those depths than you have ever managed yet!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Know that many mortals ask me for my blessings constantly, and I mean all the time, young Nephew, but for you! You needn't ask at all!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Far be it from me to raise my hand against your father, dear Nephew! Although I do suppose old Hades has it coming, doesn't he.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I've every confidence in you, young man! Now you remember that, and take my blessing here, and fight your way on out of there for me!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Nephew, I want you to go and show that surly Hades everything you're made of! And, I've arranged for you a little bit of help along the way!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: How is old Hades doing, anyway, Nephew? I suspect he's every bit as prickly as ever, whereas you are nothing of the sort!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I eagerly anticipate getting to meet you face-to-face someday, dear Nephew, just as soon as you can up and out of there!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Good Nephew, I return once more to lend to you my power! I'd like to see your discontented father try and stop you now!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: It is my solemn wish, dear Zagreus, that eventually we settle up our differences with your lord father. But for now, we fight!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Hail, my most honorable, beloved nephew, and I bring to you the blessing of Olympus, so that you might finally get out of there, already!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I just know you'll reach the surface here eventually, Zagreus! And I look forward to our meeting when you do!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: We'll keep you safe here from your father, Zagreus! But while you're still inside that Underworld, there's only so much we can do.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You've a good head on your shoulders, Zagreus, so stay positive, stay healthy, and let nothing stand between you and your goal!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I wish you well in your continued quest, and offer my sincerest blessings, and of course my power, there, Nephew!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You've seen the sheer destructive power of the heavens! Just imagine what it's like above the surface of the earth!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Someday when we'll be resting easy on these heights, why, we'll look back at this and laugh, I'm sure of it!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Ahh*, but if it isn't my most favored nephew! Striving always toward the surface of my world. Your father cannot possibly believe he can contain you, can he?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You have my blessing now as ever there, young man.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I trust you shall be getting out of there in due course, Nephew.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I shall be watching over you, young man, though it is dark down there!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: May the might of Olympus guide you through the shadows, Nephew.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Don't let your father get to you, young man, and climb on out from there.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Zagreus, we won't be giving up on you, so you keep at it, *hm*?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I shall make the heavens themselves now aid your ascent, Nephew.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You'll watch yourself down there, won't you, young man?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: All of us, we're here for you, young man!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Please do be careful not to make your situation any worse, Nephew!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I'm here for you, young man, so you take heart, and more than that, take *this*!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: All of us believe in you, though certainly no one so much as I!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Here's something I can do to help, young man!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You just take all the time you need in terms of fighting your way out of there, young man!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, don't lose heart, young man, and we'll keep at it with you here, as well!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: As my kin, you are a born fighter, Zagreus! So put your back into it, and you climb right up!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: It shall be glorious, indeed, the day you finally burst from that oppressive den into the light!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I know you have it in you to surpass your father, Zagreus. Assuming you are anything like me!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: How fares your lovely mother? Things still good with her and Hades, hm?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You tell your good lord father that his brother Zeus shall be always watching over you!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I trust your good lord father's treating you all right?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I know you're busy, Zagreus, though someday you shall have to visit us!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I'm never quite so busy that I can't make time for family, young man!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: We're all in this together, aren't we, Nephew?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I see the boatman of the Underworld has found the means to reach you with my blessing, Nephew. Such strange alliances we forge these days!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Why here I am, young man, in such strange circumstances I might add! Luckily the boatman Charon is much easier to get ahold of than your father!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Ah, so then the boatman Charon came through for us after all, did he? Whatever means we have to reach you, we'll employ!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Your Charon there must drive quite a hard bargain, Zagreus, if he would keep you from your victory just for a bit of coin!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I thought that ferryman would be content to transfer souls across the River Styx, not rob you on your journey to the surface, there, Nephew!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: My blessing isn't good enough for you, is that the way of it, young man? How impetuous of you. *Oh*, I never!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: It isn't wise to go against me, Nephew, both in matters large and small. I am not known for being charitable to the insolent.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Perhaps you have defied me here in jest, young man. Though in such cases pertinent to my authority, you'll find I lack a sense of humor.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Audacity runs in our family, Zagreus, but my advice to you is that you keep it carefully suppressed in your relationship with me.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: What have I done, good Nephew, to deserve such scorn? Your lapse in judgment here is not so easy to forgive, yet easily punished.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Your father likewise turned his back on me before, Nephew, and we both know what has become of him. I'd caution you against this.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Apparently, the consequences of displeasing me have slipped your mind, young man. A harsh reminder is in order, then.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I did not restore order to this world, and claim the heavens for myself, only to be insulted by my own nephew!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Why, Nephew, is this all some sort of jest to you? It isn't one that I appreciate!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Nephew, when presented with a choice to side against me or not to be such a fool, do be sure to choose the latter next time, hm?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Don't say I didn't warn you, young man! I only wish that I could say you didn't insult me!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: This is outrageous, Zagreus! Even your father would agree that actions such as that can't go unpunished.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Young man, I don't know why you would do this to me, though I trust you're going to think twice, next time!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You overstep your bounds with me, Nephew! But I shall make you fall right back in line.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Ah, very well, good show, young man! And I think I shall let you off the hook, and take you back under my wing, for now.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Commendable of you to live through that, and I suspect you shall think twice next time before so brazenly defying me, won't you?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, now, no need to hold such grudges any longer I suppose, but you just mind yourself around your Uncle Zeus.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Do not spurn me again like that, do you hear me, young man? I think you do, so let's put this to bed and move along.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Oh Nephew, but I simply can't stay wrathful toward you, much as I might try! Though, better not to tempt me, just in case.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: All right, all right, let's call the score between us settled up for now. Just don't go spurning me again, you understand?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: All right, this is becoming unproductive, Zagreus. As you were!

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Oh, I don't have the heart to keep exacting vengeance on you, Nephew.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I say, such petty squabbles. Aren't we better than this, Zagreus?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Well, young man, I'd say it's best we put this little slight behind us, wouldn't you?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Pah*! All is forgiven and forgotten, Zagreus. What were we even going on about back there?

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Hahaha*, that is quite enough, that's quite enough, I say! You're still alive, aren't you?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Lord Zeus, *erm*, Uncle? Please accept this offering, and all my gratitude.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Goodness, Nephew, that's an offering, indeed! I'm thankful for your piety to me, and as a show of generosity to you, in turn, I present this!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I thank you, my Lord Uncle Zeus, for your benevolence and your thunderous might.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: You honor me, young man, as well you should, for I am ruler of Olympus, am I not? Such courtesies are shown me constantly, yet I appreciate them all.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Lord Zeus, I bid you please accept my humble offering, for all you've done for me.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Why, that is rather generous of you, and I'm grateful for it, Nephew! How good of you to make attempts at reciprocity!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: This offering is but a trifle, Uncle Zeus, for all your magnanimity.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: So fine a gift again, my dear Nephew? Would that my sons and daughters on Olympus here would show me such respect from time to time!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Please, Lord Uncle Zeus, accept this gift of Nectar in your honor, though it is such a pittance in comparison to all the generosity you've shown.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: I'm very pleased to see a show of such respect and admiration for your uncle, Zagreus. You'll go quite far here on Olympus with an attitude like that! Not everyone's as mannered, nor as wise.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: If you can hear me, mighty Uncle Zeus, I wish to make to you this simple gift, and with it send my humble wish that someday you and Father settle all your differences, and be at peace.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Ah*, most splendid of an offering, young man. And while we've yet to even meet in person, I already feel as though the two of us are close, why, closer than you must be even with your father! *Oh, hahaha*! Perhaps we ought go telling everybody *I'm *your real father, am I right?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: If you can hear me, mighty Uncle Zeus, I wish to make to you this simple gift, and with it send my humble wish that someday you and Father settle all your differences, and be at peace.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: *Ah*, most splendid of an offering, young man. I already feel as though the two of us are close, why, closer than you must be even with your father! *Oh, hahaha! *Perhaps we ought go telling everybody *I'm *your real father, am I right?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: King of the Olympians, Lord Zeus! Forgive this offer of Ambrosia, for I know you have no limit of it there. But here, it is the finest gift that can be given, and even still it isn't anything compared to all you've done for me. Thank you, Uncle.

Speaker: Zeus
Text: Now, now, Nephew, you are most generous, indeed, in showing all this deference to me. But we must keep some distance, shouldn't we? Lest all the others here, why, they would be most jealous if they caught me playing favorites! Even though you *are *my favorite! Presently, at least.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Well, my hellborn kin, I have to say that there are times I wish I could have been acquainted with your father somewhat more, if you'll forgive my saying so. My father and my uncle, here... they're predisposed quite differently than I.

Speaker: Poseidon
Text: Perhaps if you were not so odd, and made more effort to be somewhat more approachable, Ares, then we'd have more in common, you and I! Should you need any tips on that, why, you just let me know!

Speaker: Ares
Text: I wished only to speak to you in private once again, my kin, except, you see...

Speaker: Athena
Text: ...Except you see, dear Cousin, that some members of our family are predisposed toward the unspeakable. I caution you around my half-brother, is all. Now carry on.

Speaker: Ares
Text: You interrupt me once again, dear sister. You know I do not care for that. I warn you to stay out of my affairs. I shall aid my kin as I see fit.

Speaker: Athena
Text: You only do as you see fit, Lord Ares. Mind that you continue pulling in the same direction as us all.

Speaker: Ares
Text: I so anticipate the day you finally arrive upon Olympus. There are few amongst us here with interests such as those I think we share.

Speaker: Aphrodite
Text: There are at least a few of us who share such interests here, isn't that so, Lord Ares? As for *you*, dearest, you take all the time you need!

Speaker: Ares
Text: Wars waged over love, my kin... can you imagine that? The lady Aphrodite and I can endlessly discuss such circumstances. I trust, from time to time, you stop to ask yourself how come you choose to fight. Not that you need a reason, of course.

Speaker: Aphrodite
Text: Oh, Lord Ares, truly there isn't the need to cloud our little godling's thoughts and judgment with such comments, is there, *hm*? Let's give him what he wants, and we can carry on in private, about that.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ah, my kin! I was just inquiring with Lord Dionysus here, under which circumstances are the greatest mortal feasts of all prepared? Because I have a certain hunch, regarding that...

Speaker: Dionysus
Text: Yeah, yeah, Ares, I will hand it to you, man. There's nothing like a feast after a war, all right! Provided you're on the surviving side, that is! Otherwise I guess they'll be feasting with *you *down there, Zag!

Speaker: Ares
Text: The cold of death is quite becoming of the Goddess Demeter, do you not think so, my death-dealing kin? She is becoming well accustomed to it, too.

Speaker: Demeter
Text: I think that you forget yourself, Lord Ares, sir. For I am much your elder; my famines had already slain the mortals by the tens of thousands by the time such thoughts of doing so first crossed your mind.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ten thousand souls have fallen to you, now, my hellborn kin. I am rather beside myself, I must admit. Fine work.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Here goes, then. In the name of Hades! Olympus, this is an official message! Lord Ares, please consider our proposal... once you're able to decipher it.

Speaker: Ares
Text: My, what is this, my kin? Some sort of invitation for me, I presume. Not just for me... this symbolizes all the others, here? Most intriguing. I shall investigate the meaning of this as quickly as I'm able, then. But first!

Speaker: Ares
Text: I wish to tell you once again I had a splendid time during our recent shared festivities, my kin. At last, I've finally seen your death-filled realm firsthand! I learned a great deal. And I look forward to learning more from our successful collaboration, hm?

Speaker: Ares
Text: Lord Zeus has gotten to you first, I see? My father's gifts are generous, indeed, though... I think I can help in my own way.

Speaker: Ares
Text: The blessing of your uncle Lord Poseidon might have helped you to this point, but here: My gift shall see you further still.

Speaker: Ares
Text: You bear the blessing of Athena, yes? She would protect you from your enemies, whilst I would rather that you slay them, and be done.

Speaker: Ares
Text: *Mm*, I see you have the Lady Aphrodite's blessing there already. Love and death, together, hand in hand? Sounds most agreeable to me.

Speaker: Ares
Text: So Artemis, my lonely half-sister, got to you first? She merely helps you hunt, whilst I shall help you kill. Observe.

Speaker: Ares
Text: That drunkard Dionysus cannot help you near as much as I, my hell-born kin. Compare the gift he gave to what I offer you.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Our messenger Hermes has been in contact with you by now, yes? Perhaps you shall not see him very often, for my work keeps him rather preoccupied, shepherding souls and such.

Speaker: Ares
Text: I faintly sense the mark of Goddess Demeter upon you, *hm*? Her power over plentitude is opposite to mine in some respects. But, lately, she has channeled it in manners more agreeable to me.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ah, you bear your own father's blessing, my kin? Such a surprise... I know the two of you are now in league, and yet... I am still quite accustomed to the thought that you harbor war-like hatred for one another. Perhaps there's still a trace of that, though, hm?

Speaker: Ares
Text: Did you happen to know, my kin, that you have slain more than a hundred foes since you began your quest? You have! For I am keeping count. And I am most impressed.

Speaker: Ares
Text: You are a most impressive death-dealer, my kin. For by my estimation, you have slain at least a thousand souls down there! Souls mostly having died before, but still.

Speaker: Ares
Text: I know that you have many aspirations, my good kin. To be plain with you about my own motive for a moment: As long as you continue bringing swift and steady death, you shall have my unyielding support.

Speaker: Ares
Text: The more you slay your enemies, my kin, the stronger the bond between us, I think. Can you not feel it, too? Though, perhaps your lust for blood overpowers your other senses, hm?

Speaker: Ares
Text: Perhaps you know a god called Thanatos? The two of us are very close associates, you know. Do give him my best wishes, should you see him soon.

Speaker: Ares
Text: I trust that Thanatos is doing well? Although he brings to mortals merciful release, whilst I most certainly do *no *such thing, I do appreciate his take on it.

Speaker: Ares
Text: It is my understanding that you have grown rather close with Thanatos, my kin? A perfect choice of mate; though I confess I'd not expected Death to have affection for another save himself.

Speaker: Ares
Text: You traveled rather far down there since last we met, my kin. And that means you have dealt incalculable death. I must commend you thus.

Speaker: Ares
Text: *Ahh*, my kin! I sensed fresh bloodshed from you recently, the real kind! For you have slain the living near the surface, have you not? Mere vermin, yes, but good enough for me.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Recently, there was a burst of violence on the surface, near to where you are, but higher up. 'Twas altogether odd, but must have forced you to return once more. No matter; time is on our side.

Speaker: Ares
Text: I sense so much death at the gates of your father's realm, of late, my kin. Now, I know that seems perfectly ordinary on the face of it, except... there's something more. I wonder if *you *know the reason why...

Speaker: Ares
Text: I know your efforts to come here have repeatedly been thwarted, my good kin. However, we have caused such violence in the intervening time, that we must take this as a real victory. Let us continue for however long it takes.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Surely you've heard rumblings about a war which has erupted on the surface, here? Doubtless you've seen an influx of fallen mortals. It's quite a decent one, I have to say! Though, unlikely to rise to the ranks of the greats. Too few armies involved in it, I fear.

Speaker: Ares
Text: War's such a wondrous thing, my kin. It solves so many different problems, whilst perpetuating its own inevitability. Let's keep it up, then, hm?

Speaker: Ares
Text: Do you ever think to yourself that you were born a bit too late, my kin? For my part, I wish that I could have been there myself when my father and the others waged ferocious war against the Titans. Ah, it must have been a sight!

Speaker: Ares
Text: I sense that you have forged a greater bond with your instruments of destruction there, my kin. Then that is very good. And may their altered forms serve you quite well.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Why, I believe that is the Frost Fair Blade you bear! I understand it shall become the instrument of choice of yet another god of war, someday. I long to meet him, this fellow student of death.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ah, that blade of yours... it looks as though it could relieve a mortal of his head with ease. Excalibur, is it? I've studied all the Fates' designs, and this one is among my favorites.

Speaker: Ares
Text: The fated bow Sharanga, in your grasp! That is not a form I'd expected you to wield. You have exquisite taste in weaponry, my kin!

Speaker: Ares
Text: Is that the fire-eating shield of the great warrior Beowulf, which you have there? I knew the Fates had plans for it, but I did not expect for you to be a part!

Speaker: Ares
Text: Those are the gauntlets of the fated king Gilgamesh, are they not? A bringer of destruction, and an agent of the Fates. You are full of surprises, my kin!

Speaker: Ares
Text: You bear the warring instrument of one called Lucifer, I see. I've little to go on about him, but it is clear he knows a thing or two about destruction, is it not?

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ah, you bear the Blood-filled Vial which I granted you! The mortal's blood contained therein... I drew it myself! Too seldom am I able to become directly involved in such matters.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Know that I admire your Lord Father very much. For his grim work lets me continue mine. I trust that one day you shall settle your dispute.

Speaker: Ares
Text: You are the son of Night herself, they say? A fascinating character, ill-liked upon Olympus, although I myself have always longed to meet her.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ah, my favorite Underworld death-dealer. I so look forward to the pain you shall inflict this time around.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Would that a sudden scourge of war would help you out of your predicament. Why, I would stir one up for you without a second thought.

Speaker: Ares
Text: Ah, my closest kin in all the Underworld, I see you there, I think! What sort of violence shall we sow together this time, you and I?

Speaker: Ares
