Text: Master Chaos, forebear of the gods, it is an honor to have met you. Please, accept this gift.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: Seldom do mortals or immortals think of making offerings to me. As I do not expect such token gestures, I am very much amused, and I accept.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Master Chaos, I pledge never to forget you or your good graces. May your wisdom and your whim forever guide me.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: Is this an offering of fealty or friendship, Son of Hades? I do not wish to know from you the answer, so that I might dwell on it and all the possibilities.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I'm ever-grateful that my journeys through the Underworld mean that we can get to know each other, Master Chaos.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: Your repeated generosity with me is starting to become a bit predictable, and yet... somehow, I nonetheless appreciate it, still. How very odd.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Master Chaos, it's little wonder all existence sprang from you, because I see the noble qualities in so many I've met embodied in you. Please, accept this gift.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: If it is unclear yet, Son of Hades, I shall not be giving more to you in exchange for your repeated offerings. You give them to me knowing it shall serve no purpose and achieve no end. I know that there are some among both mortals and your kind for whom this is quite unacceptable.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: This is the greatest delicacy of Olympus, Master Chaos. It's for you. I think normally it would be difficult for the Olympians to get it to you here.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: You make an even greater offering to me, knowing it shall produce no material result. You are aware that I am not persuadable? Yours is a squandering of resources and time. Although, of course, we do have each of these in great supply. Now then, respond.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: ...I just think the act of giving isn't quite the same as an exchange. I know I won't be getting any sort of other talisman or something in return. But, through these offerings, I can express my thanks. That's worth it by itself.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: ...I see. So then, the action is akin to theft. For you are getting something in return that I did not intend to give. I still have much to learn from my creations, Son of Hades. So let us say that we have made an even trade. My learning for your worth.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: If you'll forgive me, Master Chaos, this Ambrosia is intended to be given to those whom I care about, and I can think of few recipients I'd like to have it more. Please.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: I shall accept this, as a final offering, O Son of Hades. For I have given it additional consideration, and decided that my previous analysis of your intentions was too narrow, too inaccurate. And, I regret comparing what you have been doing to an act of theft. Respond?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Don't even mention it, please, Master Chaos. All of this is new for me, as well. I try never to overanalyze... my father does enough of that for all of us. I just know, when I encounter the primordial creator, I am going to give thanks. For everything.

Speaker: Chaos
Text: ...I see. Then, your response is quite acceptable. And, since the act of giving is not an exchange, let us say that you already had my gratitude.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Stupid boy. I told you nobody gets out of here, whether alive or dead. Though, how was your wanton ransacking of my domain?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Greetings, Father. My ransacking was a delight, thank you for asking. So, I'll just be on my way, again.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Be on your way, indeed. What do I care? You shall never reach the surface. Go, see for yourself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What is it, now? I've a mountain of infernal parchmentwork.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Out of my sight, now, go.

Speaker: Hades
Text: To what do I owe the pleasure, boy? For I'm unaccustomed to being approached by you here in my House.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, you know. Just thought I'd check in, see what you were up to. Parchmentwork going all right, I'm sure?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Oh yes, the parchmentwork is going splendidly. Would you care for some? There is no shortage of it, you see.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, what happened to the lounge? The only place for anyone to have a little fun around here, and you seal it shut.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Oh, I had little choice about that, boy. You see, after you fled the first time, Cerberus, why he was very much upset. Utterly tore the place to shreds. It's now under repair. All thanks to you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're really blaming me for not minding the dog while I was out, and while you all were here?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I lay the blame entirely upon you, yes. Who else? It's fortunate that Cerberus has calmed himself since then! Come to his senses, I should say. May you yet come to yours.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Who's that sniveling shade to your immediate left, there, Father? Already found someone new to do the busywork. And here I thought I was utterly indispensable.

Speaker: Hades
Text: That shade, boy, is my newly designated contractor; one whose responsibility is to work on this House. Though, who shall pay for everything my subjects here demand, I do not know.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're trying to guilt me into funding the exorbitant furnishings you desire.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Perhaps once we are finished with repairs for all the carnage you have sown throughout my realm, then we might finally have time for all the needed renovations that have piled up.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You have been keeping our contractor rather busy, I must say. Commissioning these frivolous projects around the House with the wealth you wrest from my domain. What are you hoping to achieve?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, you know, just giving back to the community. Figure if I'm to keep getting dragged back here it might as well be somewhat livable.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Livable! When last I checked, making the Underworld livable was not among our top priorities. Just remember, in your brazenness, whose House this is.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: There's quite a lot of renovating to be done, isn't there, Father. Your House Contractor there has shown a wide variety of pending jobs.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I've ordered Nyx to supervise that list. Entirely her problem, boy. And likely yours. How does it feel, knowing that your rampages create the need for so much maintenance?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Feels pretty good, now that you mention it. Keeps everybody occupied, no?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know, Father! I must say ransacking your domain beats having to toil endlessly in the administrative chamber. Far less painful, really.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hah! *Is that your way of asking me for your old job back, boy? You were a scourge upon every administrative duty to which you were assigned.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Yes, please, Father, give me back my old, wretched job, won't you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Privileges are *earned *not begged for, boy. Unless you plan to reimburse this House for all the income that we lost because of you, then you shall not so much as set foot in the administrative chamber, again.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: How much is the reimbursement fee, anyway?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Whichever exorbitant amount the House Contractor has on record, now leave me be!

Speaker: Hades
Text: So help me, boy, I cannot fathom why you would have bought back the authority to enter the administrative chamber once again.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I knew you thought I'd never do it under any circumstances, Father. That seemed reason enough. Though, fear not, I've no plans to reapply for a position there.

Speaker: Hades
Text: That does alleviate a deeply rooted fear of mine, in fact. The scene you caused in your brief time there yet remains a widely talked-about event among the shades who toil for me still.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Always wanted to ask you something, Father. Whose skull is that there on your shoulder? If it's not too personal.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I did not chronicle all Typhon's wretched offspring, boy. No one did. Some of them sit upon our shoulders now, lest we forget that things could easily have turned out rather differently, and much, much worse.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So these are just the remains of the spawn of the most hideous monstrosity of all time, which you and your brothers slew, got it. I guess putting the dead in their place is all part of the job. I can hardly imagine what it was like before you and the Olympians took charge.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Be certain that you take appropriate precautions with the Sigil of the Dead that you now bear. Should some misfortune come to it through negligence, it cannot be replaced.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I can't imagine what I'd do without your blessing, Father! But, thank you again. I don't often inherit Fate-appointed honors, and will take good care of it. Though... what if the Olympians catch on? Wouldn't do for everybody knowing that you're aiding me even a little, right?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Correct. It would not do, at all. Fortunately, the power of the Unseen can remain well-hidden as it pleases. What is it your instructor always says?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: ...Fear is for the weak?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Those Chthonic Companion things you have from Nyx, or whoever they ended up with... I know they have been benefiting you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Yeah, well... I'm to attempt to escape this place by any means necessary, right? I figure if I can call on Olympus for aid, maybe some of my friends can help me in a pinch, as well.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Not what I mean. Some of your *friends *have been reluctant to engage against me during our scuffles on the surface. Know that I have authorized them to proceed, if necessary.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Wait, really? You're saying it's OK for your own loyal subjects to side against you up there? You won't take it out on them?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I consider it an expansion of their responsibilities. Now, go.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So tell me, Father. Just how much did it hurt your soul knowing my face is up there on the Featured Houseservant Board, for all in the lounge to see?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Has it occurred to you that I, alone, have final say about whose countenance is shown up there? Although, others who shall not be named did put in a good word for you, repeatedly.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Blood and darkness... all my life I thought that board was a joke. But seeing my face up there... it felt good. Thanks, Father. Maybe it won't be the last time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Indulge me for a moment, boy. Why bother to construct a sundial, there? Knowing full well it was my wish to have one installed. To demonstrate your awe-inspiring authority? Or to deny me the small pleasure of doing it myself?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Maybe a little of each? Or maybe you ought not second-guess my every motive and decision, constantly, searching for some sinister agenda that has yet to cross my mind?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Pah! *I would have chosen an entirely different marble texture for it, anyway.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Guess what, Father? The lounge is all tidied up. Your House Contractor there is quite efficient once you muster up the necessary funds. You should try it sometime!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Are you expecting words of thanks because you paid the contractor to fix a bit of devastation that you caused? I fear it shall take rather more than that.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What if I replaced every furnishing in this blasted place, would you treat me any better then?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I suppose, boy, that there's only one way to find out. Though I suggest you save yourself the trouble.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I see you've decided to come home. Changed your mind yet, or looking for more pain and suffering?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: More pain and suffering, for sure. After all, you taught me to appreciate the finer things.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You keep telling yourself that, boy. But, mark you my words, sooner or later, this life that you have chosen for yourself shall teach you I was right.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Well that was quick. What news, boy, ready to give up, or no?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You'd like that, wouldn't you? Lucky I've got other family who believe in me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Be careful whom you give your trust. My brothers frolic on Olympus while we work. While *I *work! You're just like them. No wonder they like you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: So, how did it go? How did you die ignobly this time, pray tell? Cerberus and I can't wait to hear the tale.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: In that case, I'll spare you the details.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Fine. Your failure is quite easily imagined. How often it recurs! Almost as though my realm is built to keep you here. You, and every single soul that's ever lived. But, by all means, continue struggling.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Welcome home, boy. You're late for dinner... or, breakfast, or whatever blasted meal's next.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: That's all right, Father. I'm not feeling very hungry at the moment.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I've asked repeatedly for the construction of a sundial, but every time, they tell me no, can you believe it? Your impertinence with me inspires all.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Welcome home, boy. You're late for dinner... or, breakfast, or whatever blasted meal's next.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: That's all right, Father. I'm not feeling very hungry at the moment.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I've asked repeatedly for the construction of a sundial, but every time, they tell me no, can you believe it?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Blood and darkness, but this place is falling apart... nobody works an honest day down here.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, everybody's dead. Give them a break.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What would you even know of honest work? At least the wretched dead yet honor me as Lord. I cannot say the same for you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Have you yet satisfied your foolish urges? Perhaps a lashing from the Furies' whips would set you straight.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I had it out with them already, thanks.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Such nonsense. First you defy me openly, and now you lie. On my next meeting with the Furies, we'll have a word about all this, you rest assured.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Why, I can scarce believe my eyes, is that you, boy?! Cerberus, look who it is, he's back!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus looks mournfully toward the Prince.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: No need to drag the dog into this, Father.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Anything you say to me, you say in front of Cerberus! You might even learn a thing or two from him of listening, and of obedience!

Speaker: Hades
Text: He's back already, Cerberus! Just as I indicated.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I'm standing right here, Father.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I'm sorry he disturbed your rest again, Cerberus, you've done a good job. The realm is well defended still, to the high standard that you set.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What did I tell you, boy? Ever wasteful of your time, and mine. How fares my Underworld, *hm*?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I don't know how you can stand it.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Well, at least some things are running smoothly still. Next you go to die again, do give the tortured souls out there my warm regards.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ah*, for shame, boy. I thought perhaps you'd finally made it out.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Really...? I mean, oh, wait, you're not serious. That famous sense of humor shining through.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I jest, of course, you'll never make it out; as I keep telling you to no avail. But you've gone farther than expected. So, who knows....

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...You've been gone a while...

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I'm going to find Mother. No matter how long it takes me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: For the last time, you're not to speak about that woman in my House. You want to know of her so much, you go find her, indeed.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I know that Nyx has been abetting you. You wish to take advantage of her pity? I care not. Her powers have their limits, anyway.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: How can you... Nyx is the Night Itself, and can do as she pleases, isn't that correct, Father? You think I asked she get involved in all this business?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You, boy, have already dragged this entire household, not to mention my fool relatives, into this mess, which you've created. Which you dare call *business*.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So, tell me something, Father, if you please. Since we're more candid lately in regard to matters of my birthright here, and all... did you and Mother... how to put this? Any brothers or sisters I should know about?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I thought I told you never to invoke her here! Be thankful that you have no blasted kin. You've such weak blood, and such a temperament... why, then, would you think I'd risk another, such as you?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Sure, that's fair enough, it's just not all such things occur as planned, as I am told. From tales of your brothers and so forth.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Oh, blast my brothers, and blast you, as well! All those who know me know I have no heir. You could not rise to the occasion if you tried! And, there is no one else. You've only me. And I have only you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You call my chambers a mess, look at your desk, Father! Whatever happened to your court musician, huh, where's his sentencing parchmentwork? Stuck in Tartarus, all because he stopped singing for you on command?

Speaker: Hades
Text: My desk is far more organized than *you*, boy! And if you're so concerned about our court musician, why don't you commute his sentence, yourself? Seeing as I haven't gotten around to it yet.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Sure, happy to oblige. I'll just ask the House Contractor since you're too busy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I understand you have attempted to persuade our court musician to resume his craft. That is among the relatively useful tasks to which you have applied yourself of late.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I can't be completely sure but, what you said just now I think contained some of the component pieces of a compliment?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I'm certain that your boasts and twists of words shall soon inspire him to greater acts of compositional superiority, one of these days or nights.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I had a feeling that our court musician would eventually come back to his senses and his talents, boy. Here, yet again, my intuitions were correct. Though, you appear a bit perturbed. Don't like the song? It's about *you*!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It says I'm really the bastard son of Zeus, but also indelibly connected to the god of wine, and how your parents tore me to pieces, giving rise to mortals, but that I'm always going to be stuck here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You fill Orpheus' mind with nonsense, he produces nonsense. Nonsense I presume shall spread from this place far and wide, so everyone might know that I have nothing to do with you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I'm not worried. Orpheus plays for a very small audience.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, I met an oak nymph called Eurydice. You know her name, I think. Is it really true what happened between her and Orpheus? They say you almost let her out, so why not me?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Pah! *Orpheus is a talented musician, and a fool. I knew he would never get his beloved wife out of here. There's no escape for her, or anyone, including you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So you tricked him. Or maybe offered him a deal in bad faith. No matter. What's it going to take to waive the separation order between them?

Speaker: Hades
Text: That's non-negotiable, boy. Waiving a separation order! That's a veritable fortune in dues alone. Off the table. Now, go mind your own affairs, and leave the waiving and the ordering to me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, have you ever considered that Orpheus might be much better as a court musician if you permitted him to see his muse again?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I have considered many possibilities, boy. And I trust Orpheus considered many possibilities before he signed away his rights to see his so-called muse when once he invaded my realm!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So you're forcing him to stay here for eternity just because he signed a contract with you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Contracts with me are binding! Until such time as they dig themselves out of the archives and tear themselves up! And I don't see that happening anytime soon.

Description: Hades About Singers Reunion Quest 01 B
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, let's say, hypothetically, that I could pay the dues to waive the separation order between Orpheus and Eurydice. Would you honor the new terms, or spitefully cheat me out of a fair deal?

Description: Hades About Singers Reunion Quest 01 B
Speaker: Hades
Text: I honor the terms of my commitments, boy. The rules we put in place are all that keep this Underworld in any semblance of a shape! But, what you ask is utterly absurd. The costs of processing a separation order are well beyond your means.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You voided the contract with our court musician. Used your own authority against me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So what if I did? Just gives him a bit of break from time to time. He's still your court musician, isn't he?

Speaker: Hades
Text: He is. And he knows better than to undermine me, I think. Out with you, then! I'll deal with your insubordination some other time.

Description: Hades About Singers Reunion Quest 02 B
Speaker: Hades
Text: You voided the contract with our court musician. Used your own authority against me.

Description: Hades About Singers Reunion Quest 02 B
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So what if I did? Just gives him a bit of break from time to time. He's still your court musician, isn't he?

Description: Hades About Singers Reunion Quest 02 B
Speaker: Hades
Text: He is. And he knows better than to undermine me, I think. Though, I suppose the Queen would take your side that he has paid his dues in full, by now...?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, let me ask you something work-related, here. I know the shade called Sisyphus once wronged both you and Thanatos, and has since paid a heavy price. But don't the Fury Sisters now have better things to do than torture him?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You come to *me *to question how I allocate my resources? Preposterous. I care nothing for that wretched shade. That he is tortured for eternity is but a technicality resulting from his arrogance. The terms of his incarceration are long lost!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So then if I could somehow find those terms, then theoretically, I could grant him a pardon...

Speaker: Hades
Text: If you could somehow do your job, and enact miracles, then yes! You could do anything, then, I suppose. Including waste your time on those of his undeserving ilk.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You altered one of my own pacts, without so much as seeking my consent... undoing terms that were agreed upon. Do you intend to undermine everything in this House, boy? Or only me?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Only you, Father. Good thing I've inherited some of your Fate-given authority, being your son and all. Otherwise some of your most loyal subjects would be bound by exploitive terms for eternity.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Terms that *they *chose, themselves! Terms to the benefit of this House. What if Achilles were to leave his post for the green pastures of Elysium, what then?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You could find a replacement? But it's a pointless question anyway, because he's here! He isn't leaving. He might even do better at his job, now that he has increased ability to step away from it.

Speaker: Hades
Text: A naive hope, at best. The more you step away from your responsibilities, the less you shall want anything to do with them.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Megaera tells me that you surpassed her while out there. How utterly embarrassing for her, to say the least.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I suppose you're going to punish her in some cruel fashion, then?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Oh, I've already seen to that, of course. You think she volunteered to deal with you? Nobody did. That's how ignoble a task it is.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Tell me something, boy, did you enjoy the searing heat of Asphodel? You must have thought that you'd be more resilient to it.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I'm open to a change of climate. Even if it gets a bit uncomfortable.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You know nothing of discomfort, yet. Making it out of Tartarus is nothing in comparison to what lies ahead for you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I understand that you created quite a stir within Elysium. An all-out brawl within eternal paradise!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You call that paradise? It's just a bunch of shades bored out of their former skulls, itching for a chance to feel alive again.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What would you know of it! The greatest mortals have their every need fulfilled within that place. I dread to hear what they shall say of all of this.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Tell me something, boy, because my own set of ideas on the subject is beginning to run dry: What, exactly, is it going to take for you to understand that you're not leaving here?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Perhaps you ought to have me bound next to Prometheus, and have the dreaded Eagle peck my liver for eternity?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You would have me resort to such barbarity? Blast you, boy. Punishment is not the path to rehabilitation; it is for its own sake. I'd have expected all your trips through Tartarus to have taught you as much.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I'm truly sorry that he's troubled you again, Cerberus. I know how much you value resting here, and yet, I have no better means to bar the entry to our realm than you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I thought you'd figured out by now that guilting me into abandoning my quest won't work. You're the one who should feel guilty, forcing Cerberus to block my path.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What would you know of it? Cerberus cannot be forced to do anything. He simply understands he has responsibilities.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Ah*, verify something for me, here, boy. According to the latest reports... you attempted unsuccessfully to shoplift from Charon, himself? And were consequently slain? Utterly ignoble end, even for you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *Erm*, I was *borrowing*, OK? Not shoplifting. Why didn't anybody ever tell me Charon was such a monster? I thought the boating mercantile thing made for a peaceful life.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You incur the wrath of ancient chthonic gods, and then are surprised to be destroyed by them? Have you learned nothing, after all this time?

Speaker: Hades
Text: How are you finding my old trusty spear, then, *hm*? Or perhaps you have a preference for my brothers' and my sisters' former arms. Kept under lock and key, and yet, they're now in your possession, it would seem.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: The weapons in the courtyard. Of course you know about them, by now. I stole them. Why not just take them from me? I'd be stuck.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The thought has long since crossed my mind. However, I'm not fool enough to tamper with those cursed things. They go where they please. They cannot be contained. Like you. Now, why don't you go entertain each other more?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Megaera and her sisters ganged up on me that time. I didn't think anyone could talk her into working with Alecto and Tisiphone again. Or even be in the same chamber.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I can be quite persuasive under certain circumstances, boy. Though my advice to you, not that you'll take it, is not to discuss the matter openly. Megaera is a professional; but she has made her feelings on the matter clear.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It is woefully infrequent that I've cause for this, but I do have to thank you, boy. You've culled the Satyrs and the vermin bringing ruin to our Temple, there! Blasted creatures multiply at an alarming rate.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: They're not doing your bidding, yet they're every bit as bothersome as all your wretched servants I've met. I'm surprised you aren't getting along.

Speaker: Hades
Text: They are a plague upon this realm, although we have them well contained, for now. And once they are rightly dead, they tend to swear to me their fealty.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, you always said the Olympians wanted nothing to do with our kind. But doesn't Charon work directly with Hermes? Maybe it's *you *who wants nothing to do with *them*.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I want nothing to do with them, correct. My hasty nephew assists Charon out of necessity, alone. Not even Thanatos is able to keep up with the rate at which mortals expire and must then cross our borders.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Want me to pitch in? Just give me your blessing and I'll head straight for the surface.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hahaha*, no. I think not, boy. You are born of this realm. The surface is a wind-swept waste. You don't know how good you have it here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: She is gone, boy. She is gone. You are never going to locate her. I thought you would have come to that conclusion for yourself, by now. But apparently it must be said.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You mean Mother. How would you even know? You said reaching the surface was impossible as well, and I'm in striking distance.

Speaker: Hades
Text: This is my final warning to you, boy... to cease this mindless quest. Or else, the consequences shall be worse than what you have experienced thus far.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Whatever you did to my blasted seat is of no consequence to me. From my vantage-point, I can't even see it! A foolish prank and waste of valuable resources, nothing more.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It's more for everybody else than you, Father. Think of it as a tribute to Cerberus! Besides, you really should think about changing up the look of this place from time to time. Keep things fresh!

Speaker: Hades
Text: The limitless work keeps things fresh enough as it is. Though if making aimless changes in this House is how you choose to spend your limitless time, I'll have no part of it.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, of all the skeletons and such in your direct employ... you wouldn't happen to have any here around the House, would you? Out in my courtyard, for example?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Skeletons*! I'm sure they'll welcome you when next you visit Asphodel. You may not realize it, boy, but we have a certain standard of decency we uphold around here!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You ever think of giving Thanatos a break, Father? He seems to have more than his fair share of work of late.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Blame the blasted mortals for perishing so easily, or blame Lord Ares, prior to accusing me. With their surface wars, not only do they kill each other readily, but also often subsequently perish from the consequences of it all!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What wars, what's going on up there? Why don't the other Olympians do something?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Pah*! How should I know? The mortals are equipped to settle their petty differences by any number of means. We have to make room for them all sooner or later, regardless.

Speaker: Hades
Text: So, you had a run-in with the Minotaur out in Elysium, did you? Perhaps the only soul within this realm more bull-headed than you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: How long have you been waiting to use that line, Father? Wouldn't put it past you to have sent the Bull of Minos to Elysium entirely so we could have this conversation now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You give me too much credit, boy. The Minotaur resides where he resides because of an entirely different arrangement.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: He's working for you, isn't he? You think he can stop me.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Most in Elysium jump at the opportunity to do my bidding. Not that you know what that is like. Now go, see how you fare against the bull.

Speaker: Hades
Text: How goes your heated rivalry against the greatest king of Athens lately, boy? Your battles with him and the Minotaur must be the talk of the Underworld of late.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Admit it, Father. Theseus was the only hero you were able to recruit to stand against me. All the while he gets to boast about being the champion. What, was Heracles too busy for the task?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Speak not to me of Heracles. You know these heroes by their deeds, not by their character. Heracles is fortunate he's in my brother's favor. Else he would be in Tartarus where he belongs. The mortal concept of what constitutes a hero is absurd.

Description: Hades About Nyx Chaos Reunion Quest 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: I know what you did. Stay out of Nyx's affairs next time, boy. She is needed here! Not wallowing in the primordial dark.

Description: Hades About Nyx Chaos Reunion Quest 01
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're just angry because some of us still want to have anything to do with their parents.

Description: Hades About Nyx Chaos Reunion Quest 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: Parents, *pah*! You know nothing of what parents are capable of. Conspire all you like against my wishes, I care not. Get out.

Speaker: Hades
Text: So you were able to dispatch my Hydra, boy. Right down to the last hateful head. It's an accomplishment I felt was certainly beyond your talent set. Though, here you are again, nevertheless.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You cheated me. There wasn't anywhere that I could go! I could have gone much farther. All the way to Mother!

Speaker: Hades
Text: You shall do no such thing. Besides, if you were any help to me, you'd know vast portions of my realm are presently still under renovation. You won't be getting farther than you have.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I can wait. You can't just keep this place on lockdown for eternity. The mortals up there wouldn't stand for it.

Speaker: Hades
Text: They have no patience, yes. The same as you. Then wait, with all the rest of them. It matters not to me. For I have other work to do.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Now you begone from here, get yourself killed some more for all I care.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Well, boy. Word has reached me that you were able to dethrone the Champion of Elysium as well as his bull-headed companion. Tell me, how did you accomplish such a thing?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: First, you tell me when I can get out of there. The path guarded by Theseus was sealed! Is there even a surface? Is the outside world all a lie?!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Ah, now you are asking the big questions! Comforting to see such growth of character. Well if there is an outside world, you shall not be seeing it for quite some time. You know why, don't you?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Ongoing Underworld renovations?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Ongoing Underworld renovations. Now go and let King Theseus drive that sharp spear of his into yourself some more, until such time. The mortals soon shall force me to reopen, and then what?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You are late, boy! Have you any idea what time it is?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: No. Wait, what? I just vanquished you in single combat, and that's all you have to say to me?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Vanquished *me*? *Hah, hahaha*, nonsense. Don't you think I would recall such an event?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You can't be serious. You're going to pretend as though it never happened?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Everything is as it always was. And so shall it be, until the Fates determine otherwise. Or until our ongoing Underworld renovations are finally complete. Whichever comes first.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So you're really not going to answer my question about Mother from the other time, until the Underworld renovations are complete?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I know not what you're going on about, there, boy. Although, my focus is entirely upon our renovations, yes. Perhaps someday or night when this place is in proper working order, I shall have more time for your insipid questions.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You are *late*, boy! Have you any idea what time it is?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: No. Wait, what? I vanquished you in single combat and finally found Mother, and that's all you have to say to me?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hah, haha*! Nonsense. Don't you think I would recall such an event?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You can't be serious. You're going to pretend as though it never happened? She wants answers, same as I do. She demands you let me pass! Let me go to her again.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Silence! This discussion is over. I hardly think this is the time or place to indulge your overwrought imagination.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I told you, boy. I told you! There's no escape from here. Learned that the hard way, then?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You could have told me more important things. Mother left because she never even knew I was alive. Thanks to you! She's got a lot of questions, herself, as you can probably imagine. I'm headed back to her. You going to cooperate?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hahaha*, nonsense! Listen to me: If you have any sense remaining in that head of yours, I caution you not to discuss this here and now.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Let me go. Let me find her. She demands it!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Quite a mess you've created, I must say, Father... after being of no help whatsoever when it comes to disentangling it all. Though, this isn't the place to talk, right?

Speaker: Hades
Text: No! It most certainly is not. Though, I take it it shall not be long before another of our private meetings, then.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Something the matter, there, Father? You seem a little quieter than usual. Dare I say even a little somber and remorseful, for some reason?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Silence, boy! And better yet, why don't you get out of my sight? I've more important things to do now than indulge your boastfulness. We'll have to catch up at some other place and time.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know, Father, while I'm sure you don't appreciate all the distractions as of late, your ceaseless toil has had some noticeable effect. Is it my imagination, or are the ongoing Underworld renovations almost complete?

Speaker: Hades
Text: There you go, getting ahead of yourself, again. The final stages of renovation are some of the most vital! Second only to the initial planning. There's a great deal of important work ahead!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I wasn't saying it wasn't important, I was just saying maybe there's finally an end to it in sight. What are you going to do with all your spare time, then?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What's the giant pact posted out in the courtyard, Father? You offering me a job?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Perish the thought. It's so that all your toiling can be more painful, nothing more.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Why would I want my toiling to be more painful than it already is?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Who knows, boy, or better yet, who cares? To make the mortals up there worship you for all your labors? Go on, then, go get yourself dispatched some more, so I can make well certain that my realm can properly contain you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: My records indicate that you've collected earnings based on some of your accomplishments, there, boy. I suppose you need an income of your own, having decided to cut ties and all.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What, you mean the bounties that you've offered up to anybody capable of beating Meg and all your other guardians out there? Don't you think that puts a lot of undue pressure on them, knowing that you've turned them into targets?

Speaker: Hades
Text: They must do better than they have, else they shall be replaced. If they're to grow in their respective roles, they have to know their weaknesses. And so do I. That you collect the bounties for it matters not.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What about the bounties for vanquishing you? Who's your replacement going to be?

Speaker: Hades
Text: My records indicate that you've collected earnings based on some of your accomplishments, there, boy. I suppose you need an income of your own, having decided to cut ties and all.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What, you mean the bounties that you've offered up to anybody capable of beating Meg and all your other guardians out there? Don't you think that puts a lot of undue pressure on them, knowing that you've turned them into targets?

Speaker: Hades
Text: They must do better than they have, else they shall be replaced. If they're to grow in their respective roles, they have to know their weaknesses. And so do I. That you collect the bounties for it matters not.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Be sure to add those to the list of words you'll eat someday.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Saw your new Pact of Punishment out in the courtyard, Father. Impressed that you could find a parchment large enough to fit all the unpleasant stipulations. So you're taking even harsher measures to contain me?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Whether you consent to the terms of the Pact is entirely up to you, boy. But, in all your comings and goings, it is important that we have full knowledge of which property is being carried from the premises.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You've taken more advantage of the Pact of Punishment than I would have expected, boy. I almost wish to commend you for doing such a thing.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Almost? I've been rampaging through the worst your realm has to offer. Causing you untold inconvenience and likely a fortune in repair costs. I thought you'd be upset.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Upset? Heavens, no. Through your repeated bumbling, you have revealed a number of shortcomings in our operations, which my underlings are busy working to address.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know you sound especially despicable when you say *underlings*, don't you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Don't let me keep you any longer, boy, go forth! Try to escape again. You're helping make the Underworld a better place.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Explain to me something: How did you do it? I mean the Pact. For all of the conditions it imposed... you still surpassed me. How?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Plenty of practice, regular exercise, a positive attitude, the blessings of assorted family members you don't like, and your discarded Titan-slaying weapons I suppose. Nothing special. Why do you ask?

Speaker: Hades
Text: To think that you would squander such a talent on frivolous pursuit. You do not even realize what you have achieved, do you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Wait, wait wait wait wait, care to repeat that first part that you said back there? The *talent *part?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Would that you had a talent for listening. Begone for now.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Back to your senses, then, boy? The Pact of Punishment is not something one ought to trifle with unknowingly, in case you've yet to notice.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father... the Pact... you were so blasted strong. I had no idea! All those other times we fought... I can't believe that you were holding back. You were desperate to stop me, you could have!

Speaker: Hades
Text: We are bound by the Fates to this realm. It is ours, and we belong to it, in turn. And... I did not hold back against you. Rather... I had forgotten my old strength. Some of it since returned to me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Must have been all our vicious battles to the death? Or maybe it's from Mother being back in your life?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Pointless to even ask. What motivates us is a complicated thing. But if you long to face me with the power I once held during my own youth... you have available to you the means.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*... come, get your gloating well out of the way, so I can get back to this parchmentwork. It piled up, in my prolonged absence!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Not here to gloat, Father. Well fought back there. I can't believe I got you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Nor I. Next time, the Fates may not decide to favor you like that. If there shall be a next time.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father... look, Lord Uncle Zeus, I've been in contact with him, and he wishes to make peace. He asked for me to tell you. To tell you he forgives you for... whatever happened.

Speaker: Hades
Text: My brother Zeus... forgives me? Zeus forgives *me*?! How dare that blasted little brat! His beard may be luxurious but he's as much a child as are you. Forgives me, bah!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What did you do...? What happened between you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: None of your business! Go on now and frolic with that Lord Uncle of yours, the both of them! And don't you ever speak of him to me again, you hear me?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Question for you, Father. The name *Kore *happen to mean anything to you, by any chance?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *What*, where did you...?! *Ahh*, the cold witch brought it up, did she? Never repeat that name again, not here, nor anywhere, you hear me, boy? Know only this: The one called by that name despised it even more than I.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So let's see. Demeter's daughter went missing. She wound up down here. I... happened. Mother left. Demeter, and everyone else on Olympus apparently, has no idea. That about right? Tell me what happened.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I'll tell you nothing! Keep meddling in matters that you cannot understand, and you'll incur the wrath of Olympus on all that you hold dear. And, know that it is not for *my *sake that I'm warning you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What is it now? I see that sneering look upon your countenance, which must mean you have yet another one of your insipid questions, haven't you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Oh, this one's not insipid in the slightest. Let me get this straight. My mother's Persephone. Her mother's Demeter, but her father... evidently was some farm-boy? My red blood comes from him? And my propensity to die I guess.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You blame your ancestors for your own weakness? You should be thankful you were born with immortality! Though, your meddlesome curiosity and constant need for affirmation must certainly be from your mortal side.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Then, Mother, did... she grow older with age? Is she just going to expire as the mortals do? With demigods I hear it can go either way.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I said never to speak of her, blast you! You said, yourself, she is the daughter of the goddess of seasons! Use your fool head, for once.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Greetings, Father. Ran into Lady Demeter out there, on my last outing. Or should I say, my grandmother? What's she to you, then, ex-mother-in-law? Source of abject terror? Hard keeping track. Our family's rather complicated.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Do not invoke her name inside my House, you hear me, boy? You do not know at all what she is like. Though I can see why you two hit it off. She hated her father. Though understandably, as he was worse even than mine. Even than yours.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Greetings, Father. So! I can just... head on out there again whenever I want? Don't need to stick to any rigid schedule?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your unpredictability is one of your assets. Our defenses must always be on guard. So, yes: Go about your business as you best see fit!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: And the Olympians are going to keep helping me, thinking I'm trying to get away from you, to *them*. We can't keep this up with them forever, you know.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Tell me something, boy... Zagreus... why did you do all this? Return the Queen. Go to such lengths. At a certain point... you must have learned the way I felt about her. Yet still you persisted. If I were you... I'd not have done me any favors.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I didn't often stop to give it much thought. I just knew I needed to find her... and then as soon as I did, I knew I needed her in my life. In other words, doing you any favors was never a priority, Father. Just ended up that way, I guess.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...I see. I appreciate your candor. Nevertheless... I thank you. I do not know how you accomplished what you did, but know that I am grateful for the outcome. Even if I fail to act like it, much of the time.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Say, Father... back when you drew lots with your brothers, and wound up with the Underworld, rather than the heavens or the seas... which would you have claimed, if the choice was yours?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I do not deal in hypotheticals, boy. Each realm has its host of unenviable problems. You have never experienced the cold and sopping sea, or the blinding heights of Olympus. I have. And I assure you, you're not missing much.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Didn't you try to leave the Underworld, yourself, at some point? You once gave me that impression. I always thought it was because you hated it here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I hate not having any choice. Enjoy the freedoms that you have. As you grow long in years, you gain more burdens and responsibilities, until they bind you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father, all these shades... aren't they going to let on that Mother's back? What if word spreads... and the Olympians find out?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You are so well-accustomed to defying me that you forget there are no others, either living or dead, who would so dare. *None *in this House shall speak of this until we are prepared to make any announcements, on our own terms.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Regarding your responsibilities: Our Resources Director is available to you. In my private quarters. Normally, it would be I, alone, transferring excess resources back into our realm.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: The fabled Resources Director! So, now I get to give away the hard-earned resources I've painstakingly gathered over time?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You get to do precisely that. It is not necessary that you do. But if you wish to rise above your current station, you shall do it.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What's the point in rising above my current station? I thought our work was to be done in secrecy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It is. There is no point but pride. And pride is dangerous. Do what you will. I care not, as long as everything gets adequately done.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Regarding your responsibilities: Our Resources Director is available to you. In the administrative chamber. Normally, it would be I, alone, transferring excess resources back into our realm.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: The fabled Resources Director! So, now I get to give away the hard-earned resources I've painstakingly gathered over time?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You get to do precisely that. It is not necessary that you do. But if you wish to rise above your current station, you shall do it.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What's the point in rising above my current station? I thought our work was to be done in secrecy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: It is. There is no point but pride. And pride is dangerous. Do what you will. I care not, as long as everything gets adequately done.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Briefly, now, boy: Our Resources Director informs me you've advanced in rank. Commendable. That's all.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You are advancing through the ranks of your position, and returning to our realm the vast resources you have claimed. As well you ought. Carry on.

Speaker: Hades
Text: We cannot speak of this, except... *Unseen One*... the highest ranking that we can bestow. I never once imagined that you could achieve that rank, yourself. Or any rank of note.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You always thought too little of me, Father. Though, thank you for taking note of that. I figured I ought to give back to the realm that made me what I am.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Yes. For this is the only world we know.

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father... all this stuff with the Olympians... will you just tell me what's going on, for once? How did Mother come to join you here? What's your problem with Uncle Zeus?

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Hades
Text: I thought she already told you...! *Urgh*. Come with me. Now.

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Swear to me that you shall never repeat what you are about to hear. Swear it!

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: All right, all right, I swear. I swear, in your own name, I'll keep what you're about to say between us.... So?

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Hades
Text: So... you had it mostly right, before. After I inherited the Underworld... your Uncle Zeus felt sympathy for me, he says. Your mother, he knew she was unhappy on Olympus. And... he knew I was drawn to her. So what did he do? He brought her here. Gave her to me as a *gift*!

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You weren't expecting a gift like that. But she didn't want to return to Olympus, and you liked her, so you didn't send her away. And you're angry with Zeus for putting you in that position? Cut ties with him?

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Hades
Text: *Yes*!! The blasted fool, with all his flights of fancy! He does whatever he wants! He could have achieved a similar outcome in a limitless number of reasonable ways... rather than resort to what was tantamount to kidnapping! Even *if *she wanted to leave!

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: And now if Demeter and the others found all this out, you and Mother... even Zeus would be in a bad spot, wouldn't he? He must have a temper on him to match yours.

Description: Hades About Olympian Reunion Quest 01 A
Speaker: Hades
Text: You know nothing of tempers if mine is your frame of reference, Zagreus. Now, enough of this! You know the rest. Remember your oath.

Speaker: Hades
Text: One thing, before you depart again, boy. Until the Queen's intentions with Olympus come to pass... not a word to anyone about her presence, here. Do you understand?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I do. But she won't have to hide forever.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So, now that the festivities are over with, it's back to work like this, the same as ever?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Do you have any idea what happens when you announce the Underworld has a Queen, boy? *Urgh, damn it*! *Zagreus*, I mean. You become inundated with well-wishes from every blasted shade that wants something.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're responding to well-wishes? *Aw. *Don't you think some of your subjects are sincerely happy for you?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I never stopped to think about why pomegranates grew here in the Underworld. Mother's doing from before, then? And all that stuff she told the Olympians, about how they bind you to this place... it's all nonsense?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You know full well that the pomegranates in my realm hold a certain power beyond the tartness of their taste, boy. The Queen... she has a way with plants, you see. A bit of her own mother's gift, applied more sensibly.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You kept them growing all this time... flourishing, even, because of her.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So, what happened, when Mother first arrived, if I may ask? Some of your residents seem to remember the Queen from before. Yet the Olympians just never found out?

Speaker: Hades
Text: They had no jurisdiction here. No knowledge of our goings-on. Well, Hermes did, perhaps, but in a very limited capacity. As far as anybody knew beyond this realm... our Queen was Nyx. Ask nothing more of this.

Description: Hades About Persephone Leaves To Olympus 01
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Father... how are you doing without Mother around? Will she be all right, on Olympus?

Description: Hades About Persephone Leaves To Olympus 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: Clearly she is more than capable of handling herself. And we here have been well accustomed to not having her about.

Description: Hades About Persephone Leaves To Olympus 01
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So everything's back to normal, then? That sounds lovely.

Description: Hades About Persephone Leaves To Olympus 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: Nothing is normal, anymore. Besides! She shall return. Knowing that she shall return, is that not sufficient for you? Be patient, for once.

Description: Hades About Persephone Returns From Olympus 01
Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It's good to see Mother's back. Not that I was too concerned, but... I was definitely a little concerned.

Description: Hades About Persephone Returns From Olympus 01
Speaker: Hades
Text: I shared in that particular concern, and yes... it is good the Queen has once again returned. And she shall have to depart again before we know it, so cherish your time with her, boy!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Tell me, in brief, boy. Our own upon Olympus... are they continuing to aid you as expected?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Still showing up and lending their support. I think some of them are a little disappointed I'm not planning to come join them, though... I think they understand now that they owe the Underworld a debt. We all have to do our part, looking after the mortals. Whether alive or dead.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Indeed. I half-expected they would disappoint. Abandon you to toil on your own. At least thus far they've honored their commitment, then.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So, are you maintaining better contact now with Uncle Zeus, Uncle Poseidon, and the rest? Oh, and... is it all right for me to speak about them here?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Urgh*... I'm certain the superficial messages we have exchanged shall taper off, with time. We have always been apart, irrespective of the distance separating us. I know Zeus is content with your mother's version of events. Thus we are at peace, for now.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Wait, what do you mean, *for now*?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I mean only that our family is prone to causing problems for itself. Never content to leave things well enough alone. But if we have little to do with them... their quarrels, all their nonsense on Olympus... it should be of no consequence.

Speaker: Hades
Text: The latest reports indicate that mortals are fully twice as fearful of ending up in Tartarus as in our last evaluation period, thanks to the destruction you have caused. You are an unseen power in the Underworld. Commendable.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Commendable, me? An *unseen power*, huh. Surprised you're giving me the credit, Father.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I give credit where it's due. But the mortals? They know nothing of what transpires here. Only rumblings we permit to escape our realm... rumblings that reinforce their deepest fears about what shall transpire after their demise.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So the more havoc I wreak in the Underworld, the more mortals hear about all the unpleasantness, and... it makes them fearful of this place? If more of them lead upstanding lives, it'll keep Tartarus from overflowing, I guess.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Whatever you may wish to say, I do not wish to hear it.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You're interrupting me during my time at work.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I think I've heard more than enough from you lately.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You're willfully wasting my time, aren't you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Go, get out. Don't let me stop you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Shouldn't you be getting skewered by the dead?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Go to your room, or anywhere but here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Blood and darkness, what is it with you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Have you come up with more impertinence to spout at me?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I'll not be bothered with your disrespect.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Has it occurred to you that I'm preoccupied?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I am uninterested in conversing with you, boy.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your presence is no longer welcome here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: How possibly could I have given the impression that I wished to talk?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You realize just how much property of mine you have defaced?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Fail all you like, you're never getting out of here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You'll learn your place, the hard way, evidently.

Speaker: Hades
Text: To suffer such indignity, from my own kin.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Such foolishness as yours I scarce can comprehend.

Speaker: Hades
Text: We've nothing left now to discuss between us.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Have I mentioned that you're never getting out of here?

Speaker: Hades
Text: You're here to stay, boy. All of us are.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I'm busy now, as you can plainly see.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Blasted parchmentwork, it never goes away.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your recent efforts have proved useful to this place.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Go instill some fear in those wretches out there, would you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: He's back again, Cerberus! I'll try not to keep him for as long, next time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Doubtless I shall get you for that one next time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Another satyr outbreak to look out for next you venture there...

Speaker: Hades
Text: Be certain to give your regards to your mother as well!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Repairs for all the carnage that you sowed are already underway.

Speaker: Hades
Text: What else can we do to contain you, I wonder...

Speaker: Hades
Text: I have some catching up to do, as you can see.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Ah, we ought to reconvene the court now, I suppose.

Speaker: Hades
Text: As you can see, I must attend to all this parchmentwork.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I must say, you made a hollow mockery of Theseus that time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Our security efforts in Asphodel are evidently lacking.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Go rest yourself if need be. Though the Underworld is ready when you are.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Against my better judgment, I went easier on you that time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Thus starts and ends our brief exchange of pleasantries.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Continue to perform your duties as you have.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Cerberus there was anticipating your return.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your mother expected this most recent result of yours.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Do I appear as though I've time for conversation, boy?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Let us discuss your work performance at some other time.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Your infamy throughout Elysium has only grown.

Speaker: Hades
Text: I must admit... that was a job well done back there.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey, uh, Father. I thought, maybe, you know, here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Where did you get this...? You think you can butter me up with such trifles? Give me that, and then get out of here.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey, uh, Father. I thought, maybe, you know, here.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You owe me nothing, certainly not this. And I've nothing to give you in exchange. But fine, I'll honor our custom. Give it here.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *Erm*, Father... I know we can't exactly change the past, but we can try to move forward. Look, I know I'm not even supposed to have this stuff, but everyone likes it, won't you try it, at least? Here, take it, either way.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hrm*. I... can dispose of this properly. Speaking of disposal... I've no further need for this, here, so... rid me of it, why don't you? On your way out.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: More Nectar for the old disposal service, Father, if you don't mind. Come on, you must have tried the stuff, at least in the days before you were here! Didn't you ever enjoy yourself, at any point?

Speaker: Hades
Text: I don't require beverages in order to enjoy myself, boy. Unlike so many of your kin upon their mountain. Yet this blasted substance somehow finds its way to my domain. Then, fine! You wish for the customs here to be more akin to Olympus, why not?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Have another bottle, why don't you, Father? Not like it's going to change anything between us, right? All the Nectar in the Underworld can't change what's already happened. Or change yourself.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Hrm*. You're probably correct. You must think it is my age that makes me obstinate. Unable to change my nature. But I have always been inflexible. You think I'm proud of it? You call me *'Father' *like it's an insult. I deserve the title only as a technicality, I know.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You could start being a better father at any point. There's no one stopping you but you.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Yes, well... unfortunately, I am a significant impediment. You should be well aware of that. *You *were able to stop me. I have thus far been unable to do so...

Speaker: Hades
Text: Enough of this, boy! Even mortals know better. I don't want your Nectar, or Ambrosia, or whichever offerings. You owe me no such thing, and I shall not accept it any longer. In fact, here... you shall take all of it back!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Why? It's just Nectar, Father, lighten up. I get that you're surly about everything, but please at least try toward decency with me! If not for me, then for Mother.

Speaker: Hades
Text: How dare you lecture me? I mean... *urgh*... look. As you told me yourself... there's no changing what already transpired. And our memories are warnings. When you have lived as long as I have... you come to understand your weaknesses.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What are you getting at? You're just going to give up, stick with what's comfortable for you instead of making any real effort at making peace with your son?

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Rngh*. Listen to me. My attempts at making peace are going to be rather subtle for your tastes. I cannot change the past. And there is only so much I can do about the future. I tell you this because... I shall not lie to you again. That much, I swear.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Well? What is the latest explanation for your tardiness? Lost track of time admiring the courtyard view? Perhaps you were recuperating from your martial training. Achilles is not prone to holding back.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I... I'm sorry, Father, I just overslept. I must have overslept. How am I even supposed to know exactly when to be here, I mean, every moment every day and night, here, it's all the same!

Speaker: Hades
Text: It's *not *at all the same! The hue of Ixion's green light takes on an obviously lighter hue when it is time! You're an embarrassment not just to me, here, boy, but to this entire operation. Now get back to work!

Speaker: Hades
Text: Not only were you late, again... but then you also failed to perform even the simplest tasks that I had asked, repeatedly, that you complete. How many chances do you need at this? I am too lenient with you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Too lenient? Instead of lambasting me nonstop, have you considered, maybe, training me some more to do this fascinating work to your satisfaction? You'll forgive me if I didn't memorize every laborious detail the last time you performed your monologue about how all this works.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Excuse me*?! If I am not mistaken, you're deflecting your incompetence toward *me*? As though the Goddess of Wisdom herself has come to aid you in your time of need! I could replace you here and now with any number of simple shades, hungry to work here!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Then why don't you?! I don't want any of this. I'm not the one who drew the short lot with your brothers and got stuck here forever!! Why am I having to do this senseless parchment-pushing for you?

Speaker: Hades
Text: Why are you stuck? You're not. You're *fired*! I was wrong to think you were prepared to take on any responsibility at all. And, don't you ever invoke your uncles here again. Or I'll have you cast into the lowest pits of Tartarus. Now, get out of my administration, and my sight!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Infernal watch-dog Cerberus regards the Underworld Prince with mixed emotions, from purest joy to deepest melancholy.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You watch over things for me, won't you, boy? You know I'd take you if I could.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: How you holding up, boy, eating well lately? All three mouths full and happy?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Each terrifying maw of the infernal watch-dog Cerberus responds affirmatively, one after the next, as if to reassure the ever-doubting Prince.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Take it easy, boy. I'll probably be back here in no time.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The watch-dog Cerberus merely sulks upon his supple bedroll.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You keep an eye on Father for me, boy. Don't let him sour up everyone's mood.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus promises to do exactly that, in his own way.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: How's everything been going lately, boy? What's the good word?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The Underworld Prince's casual inquiry serves but to frustrate the infernal hound, as none of his three heads possess the gift and curse of speech.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey, boy, just me again. Here to report it's pretty dangerous out there even without you on guard duty all the time.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The venerable hound of hell barely acknowledges the softly-spoken Prince's platitude, knowing full well the Underworld is not as vigilantly guarded as in ages past.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Guess what, boy? Made it all the way to Asphodel last time! I fully understand how come you never liked it there. Now to trek on back, I guess. Take care!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Despite the Underworld Prince's optimism, his old companion Cerberus, the multi-headed hound, maintains a somewhat sulky attitude for now.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey good to see you back here, boy. I'm glad you're back on guard duty! Even if it means having to find a way past you. I know you're just doing your job.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The fear-inducing hellhound eyes the Underworld Prince uneasily, his six ferocious eyes each glistening within the dim light of the House.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I hope I haven't been inconveniencing you too much with all the visits to the Temple lately, boy. Say, how do you get back? Charon giving you a lift?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Thus asks the Prince his question of the guardian of the gates of hell, knowing full well the multi-headed monster keeps a wide berth of the river-boatman, as do all with any sense.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Enjoying staring at that ball I got you, boy? No fun if it doesn't fight back, huh...

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The hell-forged multi-headed monster feels no urgency to waste his precious time on simple play-things, much preferring to conserve his vast energy reserves in case any trespassers need to be eaten suddenly.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You really ripped the lounge to pieces, boy? I hope you didn't get yourself in too much trouble. I'm sorry to have worried you like that.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The guilt-wracked monster Cerberus admits to committing the crime, expressing some remorse for having implicated the incendiary Prince.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey, did you see, boy? The old lounge is good as new again, you ought to check it out! Just, don't annihilate it like you did last time.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Each savage countenance of Cerberus lights up to hear the news, doubtless beginning to assemble stratagems for ravaging the lounging area once more.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hey, boy. I hope all the construction and renovation around here hasn't been too inconvenient for you, lately. But hey, the lounge is just about ready for you to utterly destroy again!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Prince Zagreus implants in the impressionable, vicious watchdog of the Underworld a new appetite for more destruction, to be sated in another age.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You know, after dying in some wretched manner, giving pets to my good boy sure helps me get back on my feet. Thanks for being here for me.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The burning embers in the eyes of monstrous Cerberus, notorious hound of hell, reveal that he, too, is amenable to the pets of which the Underworld Prince speaks, and in fact is deeply grateful for the quantity of them.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I found her, boy! My mother! Persephone, you remember her, don't you? She was pleased to hear about you. But I couldn't stay for long, and I have to find her again, so... guess I'll see you at the Temple, then?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The ghoulish features of the much-reviled hound of hell all soften instantly upon the mention of a certain name; briefly, then, the monster is at peace.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well, look at you, boy! Never seen you quite so perky, relatively speaking of course, big tough guy like yourself. You must have missed Mother just as much as she missed you. Well, you've got plenty of time for catching up on things, now!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The monstrous triple-headed beast of Hades would perhaps be overcome with pure emotion by the joyous circumstances, were he only capable of this.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Bet you're happy to see Mother home again, huh, boy? Only wish you could have told me about her before.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The hell-born monster Cerberus contentedly ignores the Prince's callous, inconsiderate remark.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *Oof*, you showed me back there, boy. With Father on the surface? I know you were just playing, but... go easier on me, next time, will you?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The unrepentant monster Cerberus is thoroughly incapable of showing neither restraint nor remorse.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: We're all very proud of you, boy! You were so well-behaved at the feast. I was worried sick one uncle or the other was going to set you off at some point, but you were Patience Incarnate. Thanks for helping show our extended family a good time!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *How infernal Cerberus, the hound of hell, managed to maintain civilized behavior throughout the duration of the recent feast remains a mystery to all who attended.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The Prince and Cerberus exchange a look.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The watch-dog Cerberus observes the Prince.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus cannot be bothered at this time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus is comfortably at rest, observing all.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus lies as ever at the foot of his Lord Master's throne.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus makes no attempt to move.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus is busily considering upon what else to gnaw.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus goes about his business: gnawing, in this case.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus is preoccupied with scratching and biting at himself.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus is uninterested in conversing at this time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The hound of hell rests peacefully upon his favored spot.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *All three of Cerberus the watch-dog's terrifying countenances greet the Prince.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The vicious three-faced guard-hound of the gates of death barks out a brief hello.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The ever-faithful Cerberus remains resting steadfastly in his spot.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Notoriously vicious Cerberus is watching quietly his Master's court.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *One of the frightful maws of Cerberus busily grooms the other two.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The triple-headed monster Cerberus is dutifully sitting there as ever.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The many-headed Cerberus is busy thinking of his next savory meal.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus acknowledges the Prince with an affection tempered well with time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The hellish watch-dog snarls at the listless Shades crowding about the court.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The much-feared Cerberus licks endlessly at something on the floor.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The hound of hell barely regards the Prince, having been sated for the time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The vicious triple-headed Cerberus shows some restraint, for now.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus is too busy living in the lap of luxury to pay much heed.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The monster Cerberus sits vigilant atop his bedroll.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Each savage maw of Cerberus salivates in anticipation of the next time to feed.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Terrifying Cerberus is busy gathering his strength for when next he shall bar the Prince's path.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Look what I got for you, boy...!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *As one of Cerberus' heads receives the Prince's gift, another muzzles something back into his hand.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: There's a good boy... thought you'd like that!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus is overjoyed to have received such a delicious treat.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Only the very best treats for my best friend, right, boy?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Cerberus yawlps in merriment upon receiving such a generous offering.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It is my humble duty to oblige my favorite boy with all the treats as I am able to procure.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Knowing the watch-dog's never-ending appetite for treats, the Prince obliges him.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You like this stuff, don't you, boy? Well, good, because I like sneaking it over to you!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The delectable taste of Nectar is enough to briefly sate even the ferocious appetite of the hound of hell.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: This Nectar not fancy enough for you, boy, is that it? You've developed quite the delicate palate at your distinguished age!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Though having little appetite remaining for the lightness of Nectar's flavor, the multi-headed monster of the Underworld nevertheless accepts.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: That's right, boy... Ambrosia, just for you. You're going to love it. Pretty much every creature, living or dead, does!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The six eyes of the hideous hound of hell go wide at once from having received the exquisite gift of rare Olympian Ambrosia. The creature is rather beside himself.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Hits the spot, doesn't it, boy? I know you're caught up in the middle of all this and having to weigh your loyalties more than you'd like. I'm sorry we're putting you through this.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The Underworld Prince's next attempt to bribe the monstrous triple-headed hellhound into further liking him proves once again successful, as the kingly gift of heavenly Ambrosia is beyond compare.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Cerberus, not to get all sentimental on you, but... oh, who am I kidding, look... you've been with me my entire life! I know you're here at home partly because of me, aren't you?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The bond between a hound and its master is as hard as adamant. Cerberus, the fearsome monster born of hell, and guardian of its gates, answers firstly to the Prince's father. But it turns out, the Prince may be the next best thing.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're the best boy in the whole world. Even if heads Beta and Gamma don't much care for pets, do they? I've got more than enough lined up for you, though. Count on it.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The multi-headed Cerberus stands vigilant before the Underworld's entryway; the tales of what happens to those foolish enough to attempt to pass are far too graphic to describe.*

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So it's really come to this, boy? After everything we've been through. Well then, if this is how it has to be, there's nothing left to say. Except for: *On your guard*!!

Speaker: Zagreus
