Text: That's... that's all true. As individual statements, at least.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...Fortunately, our loving and dutiful son at last persuaded his mother and father to reveal their secretive relationship, and make an effort to rejoin their great family.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Your mother won't be happy that you left.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'll deal with her. Perhaps I'll have to visit her and the rest of them from time to time, if that's what it shall take. But I'll be back. I've no choice! Did you know that if you eat the seeds of an Underworld pomegranate, then you cannot leave for one month out of the year, per seed?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: What? No, I never knew that.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Neither do they.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: How soon is this family gathering you have in mind going to take place?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Soon after you invite them all, I hope. Now, go. And trust in me, all right? We have a lot to learn of trust, I think.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: How goes the doling out of invitations, Zagreus? Have the Olympians been amenable to the idea?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Not just amenable, Mother. Positively intrigued. I can't believe you scrambled the invitations in such a way that, only with the lot of them combined will they get all of the details!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: A bit of collaboration seemed in the spirit of things. We're a great, big family, Zagreus. Past time we started acting like one, no? Now, keep it up. And thank you for your help.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Mother, this family gathering you're planning... are all our relatives welcome? Because I was wondering if I could extend the invitation to a distant ancestor... you know... Chaos.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Nyx's parent... you've been in contact, then? Look, if you feel it's the right thing to do, I trust your judgment. The spirit of this event is to bring the family together.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Thanks. I doubt Chaos would be able to attend, though would still appreciate the thought.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It's done, Mother! Father. The invitations. Personally sent to everyone with whom I've been in contact. So, what do we do now?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Excellent, Zagreus! Congratulate him, Hades! On a job well done.

Speaker: Hades
Text: *Grr. *Persephone, how can you be so certain your request was executed to your satisfaction?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: It's known as trust, Hades. Or faith? They're similar. Try one, sometime! It'll be good for you. As for what we do next... why, we've a great, big feast we must prepare!

Speaker: Hades
Text: This House is not a suitable location for such guests! Dionysus, alone, shall bring ruin to this place! Or... *urgh*... the faith thing that you said.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Yes, good! Now then... we have a lot of work to go around, so why don't we call everyone on staff, and let them in on this, and dole out suitable responsibilities, all right?

Speaker: Hades
Text: All right....

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: All right.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: All right!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...*Whew*! I'd say that went about as well as could have been expected! And the cleanup wasn't all that bad. For the most part.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: We're fortunate Uncle Zeus seemed to catch on right away, and went along with it. But, this whole elaborate tale you spun... I remember how hurt I felt when I found out Father lied to me about you. Now we're lying to Olympus. What if they find out? Even if they don't... I don't like it.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Zagreus... I may not be an expert... but here's what I've come to understand about how families work. At least our own. The thing is... how we speak to one another is even more important than the words we use. I think, deep down, everyone in our family knows this.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You're saying they all knew you weren't being perfectly honest, and went along with it anyway? I guess the pomegranate thing in particular was a bit of a stretch.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: The common ground in our family is that we want peace. Besides Ares, though even he would rather the conflict occur elsewhere. That elaborate tale... it's less a deception, and more a concession. A way of saying let's move on from the past, and start anew. No hard feelings.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: You don't have hard feelings? What about Father? What about Demeter?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Well, let's see. My hard feelings are nothing next to the joy of having my son in my life. Your father never imagined his relationship with me could be out in the open. And my mother... she's just glad I'm alive.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: And Uncle Zeus is glad things didn't turn out worse for *him*. I get the sense he acts a bit impulsively at times, and deals with the consequences later.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: What can I tell you, Zagreus? We're family. You said it yourself to me before: We're stuck with one another. That any of us like each other in the slightest... it's a wonder and a blessing, I think.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Yeah. I know what you mean. Thanks, Mother. Think I'll be heading out again soon. See you when I get back?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I have to say, Mother, that was a clever plan. Convincing Father to finally let somebody have some fun around here.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Haha*, well! I'm glad it worked out for the best. There's just one thing that happened that I ought to tell you about, Son. No secrets between us, and all. This... is quite difficult for me to say.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It's about Demeter, isn't it. You two were talking half the night. She wants you to come home with her, doesn't she? You'll always be her little one, something like that?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Indeed... something like that. You're quite perceptive, have I ever told you, Zagreus? But yes, my mother, she was quite conflicted. Didn't know whether to smite me or to hold me, maybe both. And, yes. She asked that I come home... to my responsibilities.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: So... you're leaving...? No, Mother, you can't be leaving, you just got here!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Oh, it's not as bad as that, it's just... if we are to keep the peace down here, then, I must spend some time up there. Every so often! But, I shall always return, in no time at all. I promised Hades, and I promise you.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well then... when are you going to go?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Soon, Zagreus. Perhaps by the time you're back.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I don't suppose... I can come with you, can I?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Tsk*, you know the surface isn't good for you! Besides, you're needed here. But, if you really want to see it for yourself, someday, who knows? Perhaps eventually we'll figure out a way.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I'm going to miss you, Mother.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Welcome home, Mother! How was your trip, things go all right with you and Demeter? With... Grandmother. Still getting used to thinking of her that way.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: You know, it's funny... I think she was so overwhelmed to see me again that maybe something finally changed in her. I always thought she was utterly unyielding. She asked me if I truly came here by choice, and I put her at ease.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Ah, that's a relief. Grandmother can be rather intense, but... she's been kind to me, and very helpful, too. Do you suppose she'll ease up on the whole eternal winter thing there on the surface, now that she knows you're safe?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I asked. She told me that she would. Warmth shall return to the surface. Some of the time, at least. Likely on a rigid schedule, knowing her. And perhaps not in the vicinity of our domain. She's not the sort to forgive and simply forget.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...*Oh*, come on, Hades! Mortals are much more resilient than that! What, you think they'll show up at your gates here, all at once? They have our family looking out for them.

Speaker: Hades
Text: That is what I'm afraid of. Do you truly believe my brothers and the rest shall take the sort of care of them while they draw breath, as we do here after they have expired?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: It's true we have to look out for them indefinitely, while Olympus need only look out for them for a little while. But our relatives are always watching from their mountain! And if they do turn a blind eye once in a while... mortals aren't bad at fending for themselves.

Speaker: Hades
Text: But they are never satisfied! Always begging us to provide more, and more.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: They *like *us, Hades! They praise us, tell one another about us. What do you expect? Would you rather they forgot about us?

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...No. No, I suppose not. But they *need *us!

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...And what of the complaints from Elysium? They wanted the lawns thoroughly manicured for their athletic contests.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Already taken care of. Though, the flooding in Asphodel, *hm*, that doesn't look like something we can clear up for quite some time. Fortunately, the residents seem to be getting accustomed to it.

Speaker: Hades
Text: There have been fewer reports about it as of late. And what of the Satyr problem? Blasted things are rampant up there, still.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Well, they're probably contained up there, at least. And Zagreus has been keeping them in check, hasn't he?

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Well, be that as it may... if they pester you at all, do let me know, and I shall have them dealt with quickly.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Oh*, Hades... I think the shades around here have been through enough as it is! I don't mind them. After all the time I spent on my own, having some company has been a welcome change.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You are certain all your needs have been provided for? Because if there is anything that you require...

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Require*? Look at this place, Hades. Look at *me*! I have everything! And so do you. Try not to worry quite so much. And be patient with your son. That's all I ask.

Speaker: Hades
Text: Persephone, I cannot promise you such things, they're... not my strengths. Besides, I have a reputation to uphold! *God of the dead*! If the wretches do not fear me, or *you *for that matter... what, then?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'm not going to tell you how to balance your work, your marriage, and your parental responsibilities. I don't think anybody on Olympus or below knows quite how best to manage that. So long as we do our best.

Speaker: Hades
Text: ...Sometimes, I... still cannot believe that you are here. Returned to us. Your radiance, in all this darkness... you must miss seeing the coast.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: The coast was nice enough, Hades. But nothing is ever perfect, right? No matter how hard you try. Still... I think we get quite close around here, every once in a while.

Speaker: Hades
Text: You have taken much less time adjusting to this place than when first you joined us. Part of my surprise. I, myself, was forced to be here. I never thought anyone would come from the surface here by choice.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: The heart can make us do the strangest things, can't it?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...So if there's anything that I can do for you, Nyx, you need but ask, all right? I plan to pull my weight.

Speaker: Nyx
Text: Your services were always welcome, here. Please acclimate yourself at your own rate. I am available to answer any questions you may have at any time.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Thank you, my friend. I have to tell you... it's good to be back.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...I just don't know how I can ever repay you. For raising him. For *everything*. After I left... besides old Cerberus, I think maybe I missed you most of all.

Speaker: Nyx
Text: I can remember feeling similar emotions at the time. However, it is quite unnecessary to give thanks to me this way. You are the Queen, safely returned where you belong. I did what anybody would have in my place.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Anybody would have lovingly raised my estranged son, while keeping safe my secret, eventually orchestrating an elaborate plot to reunite him with me, so that I might someday return, to have a Nectar with them in the lounge?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Oh, Cerberus! Doubtless you deserve the biggest thanks that this House still stands, don't you? Did you enjoy the treat I brought you from the surface?

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The surface-treat-devouring hound of hell provides the Queen a most decidedly affirmative response.*

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I thought you might. You wouldn't know it wasn't made of meat, I'll bet! I'll see if we can't grow you plenty more.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: You're such a good boy, aren't you, Cerberus? Yes you are! Guarded the place while I was out. And even let my son come visit me!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The ever-vigilant and terrifying Cerberus merely accepts the praise.*

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'm sorry, Zagreus, I've pressing matters to attend to now.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Do let me know if I can help with anything, all right?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Your father's prouder of you than you think.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Go make us proud, my son.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Keeping the realm secure as ever, right?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: It's always nice to have a chat with you.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I think the House is well enough in order as of late.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I hope your last assignment turned out well.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Do give yourself a break from time to time!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I ever tell you you're the best son that a mother's ever had?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Hope my little cottage on the coast is holding up!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Please keep an eye on my garden on the surface when you get a chance.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'd say this garden's doing quite all right for now.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Don't let your father get to you too much, all right?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: You're looking just as well as ever, Zagreus.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: You show your father who's in charge next chance you get, all right?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: The pomegranate trees are coming in nicely still, the tough old things.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: You'll let me know if there's something that I can do for you?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: We have to say farewell again, for now, my son. Olympus calls, but I'll be back, all right?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I shall be leaving again for Olympus soon. I'll miss you, Son.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I must go visit Mother on Olympus, Zagreus. I'll tell her you said hi.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I have to go again, soon, Zagreus, all right? I'll see you soon.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'm due to visit Mount Olympus once again, so please be good to one another while I'm out.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Time that I headed up to Mount Olympus, though you keep an eye on things till I get back?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I have to go now, Zagreus, but I shall see you just as soon as I return.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Things are well enough upon Olympus. Though, it's a relief to have come home again.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Don't think I'll ever get fully accustomed to Olympus, Son.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Zagreus, you're the most welcome sight I've seen in quite some time.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Always such an exhausting journey, from Olympus down to here.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I trust that you and Hades have been good to one another since I left?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'll tell you, it is so much colder up there on that mountaintop.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: This is a welcome sight from all the snow-capped mountaintops.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Oh we're busy just formulating more of our dark schemes together, Zagreus.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Nyx here is a wellspring of parental advice, as it turns out!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Nyx was just telling me some more about your early days, my son.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: It seems I failed once again to persuade Nyx to take some personal time!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Please excuse your father and me for the moment, Zagreus.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Go on, Hades. Try saying something nice to him, for once.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Your father and I still have a bit of work here to wrap up.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: The work certainly never ceases, Zagreus!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: More than enough parchmentwork to go around!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Plenty of parchmentwork to contend with, I can assure you, Zagreus!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Don't go too hard on each other out there, all right?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I've heard that you've been doing great out there lately, Zagreus.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *Erm*, Mother? Was it always a custom in Father's House to secretly give Nectar to those you care about? I guess it also could have been a thing on Olympus. Look, I wanted you to have this. I'm so glad I found you.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Oh, Zagreus, you're so thoughtful, truly! Your father never permitted Nectar out in the open so I'd practically forgotten its savor. Though, just a moment, I have something for you, too!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: For me? Are you quite sure? You know, this vintage must have made it all the way up from the surface, to the mountains, then to here. We've both had distant journeys, haven't we?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well, I, for one, am certain this vintage here has journeyed to the right place. Please enjoy it.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I must confess I do enjoy having a good bottle of Nectar, every now and then. And you appear to have a careful eye for such bottles, from what I can tell!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: My careful eye has got to be the green one, hasn't it. To having a discerning eye, Mother!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Thank you very much, my son! You know, gift-giving customs of the Underworld are just so much more straightforward than the complicated social graces of Olympus!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: If there are other ways of showing one's appreciation than with Nectar and the like, well, they must pale in comparison I'm sure!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Oh*, this is wonderful, except... I'm wracked with guilt for having nothing much to give you, in return. You never even got a mother's love from me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Please don't say that, it's just a gift, all right? Besides... can't we start now? Mother and son type things. If you would like.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'd like that even more than this fine Nectar, Zagreus!

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Somebody raised you very well indeed, my son. Nyx, I suppose. I'll never be half the mother she is. She's done it for aeons! While I'm only getting started.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: For what it's worth, I happen to think you're off to an excellent start. Nyx did teach me a lot. Achilles, too, and Father, in a way. But there is no replacing your presence. I felt that before we ever met. And now I know for sure.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Thank you, Zagreus. Let's hope you're right. I nurtured very many plants, at least, of that I can assure you! Perhaps my gardening experience provided a bit of a head start on this whole mothering thing.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Mother, I know there may not be many things you miss from living on Olympus, though I wondered if perhaps Ambrosia may be one of them. And got you some, because... well, here.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...Why, this really is Ambrosia! How did you even acquire this, Zagreus? It brings back memories, for certain. And, never the bad ones, which... I think it must be why we prize this stuff so much. This is for me?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It is, it is, of course! And, it's my dearest hope that, at some point long from now, when you're relaxing with a bottle of Ambrosia, dare I say perhaps with Father... that these memories will be among the ones that spring to mind.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Oh*, my son... I shall certainly not need Ambrosia to think back upon getting to know you with the greatest fondness. Thank you very much.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Here, Mother. More bottled pleasant memories for you. I know you're glad you've long since left Olympus, but... I'm glad you were there, because the experience of it must have played no small part in making you who you are.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: You know, the last bottle you gave me brought more pleasant memories than I expected. No telling just how many more of them I've tucked away. Say, would it be all right if I shared this with your father?

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: It is yours to do with as you please.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: *Haha*, almost sounded like a *no *to me!

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *No*! I mean, yes, please share it with Father, if he would be willing... I imagine what few pleasant memories he has are all of you.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: Nonsense, there's also Cerberus! Present company excluded. Come on, Son. Your father has a lot of work to do, but I'm absolutely certain that he has fond memories of you. Though, I know that isn't reassuring, coming from me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Everything is somehow reassuring, coming from you, Mother.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I thought about it more, Mother, and I would like very much if you and Father were to share this. Though, maybe don't let on where you got it, just in case?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: This is splendid, Zagreus, but please! If there's one thing I've learned since we met, it's that the trust we share is at the very foundation of our relationships. Why shouldn't he know who this is from? Besides, I think he could figure it out.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: Well, when it came to the Olympians, you said yourself that there was only so much truth that they could tolerate. Are you sure Father would be tolerant knowing I got this for the both of you?

Speaker: Persephone
Text: I'm sure enough! And if he isn't, I suppose it's more for me.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: *Haha*, well! Just as long as someone puts it to good use.

Speaker: Persephone
Text: ...You know I always wanted to be a mother, Zagreus? But after you were born... I was certain I had lost my chance. Then one fine morning you just walked into my life. And here we are. I still cannot entirely believe it. What I mean is... I love you, Son. I'm doing my best.

Speaker: Zagreus
Text: I know. I love you, too, Mother.

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Concealed in the dark recesses of the Underworld is the land of Erebus, wherein the dead await eternal sentencing; they long for the attention and good graces of their master, the Lord Hades.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *A hidden stretch of the boundless river Styx cuts through misty Erebus, providing for the river-boatman Charon a locale in which to deal with the unruliest of souls.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Having traversed the flaming river Phlegethon to gain this vantage point, relentless Zagreus must now confront a foe of unimaginable savagery, who lies ahead, awaiting patiently its time to strike.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Within the suffocating heat of Asphodel reside the vast majority of those who lived upon the earth and died. There they persist until the end of time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The act of sorcery often ends in an untimely death and an eternity in Tartarus for careless souls, though some are able to perfect the trade, and take up permanent residence elsewhere...*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The searing flame and ashes of the river Phlegethon mean nothing to the ferryman, Charon, who travels all the waters of the Underworld, bearing the dead, the damned, and all their fineries.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Hidden well within the limitless inferno of the river Phlegethon, somehow, a trickle of life-giving water yet remains; as though provided by the Fates themselves unto the very lucky Prince.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The once-verdant plains of Asphodel are now engulfed in scintillating flame, having been flooded by the river Phlegethon, whose hideously superheated contents could bring death swiftly even to those resistant to most heat.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Within the suffocating heat of Asphodel reside the vast majority of those who lived upon the earth and died. There they persist until the end of time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The magnificently ominous facade of the great Elysian Stadium looms tall above the rabble-rousing Prince, as if to goad him into such a competition which he cannot hope to win.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The vast and multitudinous riches of both the surface and the Underworld are hoarded by the river-boatman, Charon, whose services are often tendered to the wealthiest within Elysium.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Within the delicately hewn constructions of Elysium exist places of peace so utterly serene and absolute as mortalkind is seldom to experience during the average short and often-painful coil.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Amid Elysium's moss-covered chambers, carved of stone, stand untold numbers of eternal monuments in tribute to the greatest heroes which mortality can offer, there to honor them in life as well as death.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The rare, heavenly splendors of Elysium, reserved for only the most great of mortal souls, spread forth luxuriantly all about the fire-stepping Prince.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The enshrouded river of forgetfulness, Lethe, flows through the hallowed chambers of Elysium, numbing old pains and memories of the most-noble shades residing there.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The deepest reaches of the Underworld... the void from which all life and consciousness sprang forth during the dawn of time... the realm of Chaos. A land almost unseen even to denizens of death's kingdom.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The fathomless expanses hidden in darkest corners of the Underworld stretch well past the notice of Lord Hades himself; and yet, the interfering Prince somehow discovers passage there.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Within the Underworld's quietest, most solitary, darkest abyss lies hidden evidence of the beginning of all things, of Chaos! The most ancient sculptor that has shaped this world.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Inside the filth-encrusted lairs carved into the looming edifices of the Underworld lie such terrible abominations that not even grim Lord Hades is inclined to speak of them.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Deep within the desecrated lair of the god-defiling Satyrs lie the noisome contents of their profane rituals, so foul as to be indescribable.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *At last the willful prince has ventured all the way up to the surface of the mortal realm, yet still he is encased within the earth itself: the gateway to the Underworld, a threshold from which there is no escape.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The vast Temple of Styx and its innumerable dangers now are all that separate the Underworld Prince from the land outside, which he so desperately longs to see.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Not far from here, the dead begin their journey to their final resting-place down in the depths below; and so the river-boatman Charon often passes through.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The widely-feared and many-headed Cerberus, the Underworld's sentinel, presides over the entrance to this realm, devouring whole those fool enough to make attempts to flee.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *A crudely-hewn network of tunnels grows from one of the cold Temple's flanks, containing vicious denizens unwelcome in this realm, even in death.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The surface, wind-swept, wracked by freezing cold, nonetheless instills within the prince a sense of awe, and the sublime. For it is unlike anything that he has seen.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *All manner of fruits and vegetables thrive within the hidden gardens of Persephone, the one-time Queen of all the Underworld. A world of life, far from the realm of death.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Beyond the present chamber lies the outermost perimeter of Tartarus, promising terrifying dangers far beyond the Underworld Prince's reckoning.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The Erinyes; known also as the Furies, they are the trusted sentinels of Lord Hades, charged with torturing the worst of mortalkind... and ridding the Underworld of any fool enough to trespass where they do not belong.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The path from Tartarus is finally laid bare. Far above, the heat from Phlegethon, the river of flame, is faintly felt already... even as its dangers lie in wait.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *None, other than those in the trusted inner circle of Lord Hades, are authorized to enter the intricate chambers connecting the vast regions of the Underworld; but the Prince decides to barge in, anyway.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The most violent wretches of Tartarus are sealed away even from other condemned souls; their only visitors, those fool enough to attempt escape.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Damned, lost souls with nowhere left to turn congregate in deepest Tartarus, where they fuse together with the earth itself into odious forms which defy description.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *A place of calm and respite, whilst perhaps unimaginable in the Underworld, occasionally is to be found, in fact.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The infernal wares of the stygian boatman, Charon, lie sprawled about, available for sale to whomever would be willing to quench the boatman's great thirst for riches.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *The River Styx flows infamously through the Underworld, offering the boatman Charon expeditious travel from the realm of mortals to the lowest depths, where many of their shades reside forever.*

Speaker: Poseidon
Text: I have to tell you something, little Hades: My relatives and I, we've been holding back one of our greatest gifts!! To see if you were worthy. And you are! My aid is yours, so call me if you need anything! Especially to smash your enemies to bits.

Speaker: Poseidon
Text: Nephew! I'm mightily impressed with your ability to cull those rivers there of all the denizens of my domain! Your crusty father's not entitled to the bounties of the sea! But, on my limitless authority, you *are*! You have my Rod of Fishing... now have *this*!

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Composed of such innumerable ever-shifting interlocking chambers, the Underworld of Lord Hades all but guarantees the dead shall there remain until the end of time.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Each time the Prince delves back into the Underworld, its ever-shifting chambers realign to frustrate his attempts to perhaps map it out.*

Speaker: Storyteller
Text: *Within the depths of Tartarus reside the most wretched of all the shades who linger for eternity within the Underworld, whose Lord and Master is especially unkind to those attempting to cheat death.*
